	+ Opaque coating applied on die edges to prevent stray light
* **Applications**
	+ Simultaneous imaging of multiple planes

<summary>

• The text describes a system and method for transferring network administrative functions from a master device to a slave device in a home network, to minimize power consumption.

• The network includes various devices capable of performing specific nominal device functions, and communicating with each other via a network medium.

• The devices are categorized as network master nodes or network slave nodes, with only one device serving as the network master node at a time.

• The network master node performs network administrative functions, such as beacon transmission, device association and authentication, admission control, and bandwidth assignment.

• The network slave nodes receive data enabling the network administrative functions from the network master node, and become the new network master node.

• The network master node determines if there is any traffic on the network medium, and sends a transfer request to the network slave nodes if there is.

• The network master node selects a particular network slave node to transfer the network administrative functions to, based on predetermined selection criteria.

• The network slave node receives a request to transfer a network administrative function, sends a request reply, and receives the transferred network administrative functions to become the new network master node.

• When any device becomes activated, it checks for the presence of beacons on the network, and becomes the network master node if none are found.
</summary>

• The seal supported subminiature lamp assembly utilizes a high temperature polymer that surrounds and is in compression contact with the glass envelope.
• The polymer may preferably derive support from a metal base.

• Advantages of using high-dielectric materials in semiconductor circuitry:
  • Provides several advantages such as ferroelectric properties and size reduction of capacitors.
  • Pb/Bi-containing high-dielectric materials are convenient due to their low annealing temperatures and desirable properties in small grains.

• Challenges in integrating non-SiO2 based oxides directly or indirectly on Si:
  • Strong reactivity of Si with oxygen results in the formation of a SiO2 or silicate layer at the Si//oxide interface.
  • This layer is generally amorphous and has a low dielectric constant, which degrades the usefulness of non-SiO2 based oxides with Si.
  • High-dielectric constant oxide (e.g. a ferroelectric oxide) can have a large dielectric constant, a large spontaneous polarization, and a large electrooptic properties.
  • Ferroelectrics with a large dielectric constant can be used to form high density capacitors but cannot be deposited directly on Si because of the reaction of Si to form a low dielectric constant layer.
  • Such capacitor dielectrics have been deposited on "inert" metals such as Pt, but even Pt or Pd must be separated from the Si with one or more conductive buffer layers.

- Invention overview
-- Relates to network implemented shared workspace environments
-- Focuses on spontaneously setting up collaborative work-sharing environments between physically distant individuals
- Background
-- Collaborative work-share environments include video conferencing, document sharing, and shared "whiteboard" systems
-- Expensive, dedicated equipment is typically used for videoconferencing, while more economical PC-based products have been introduced
-- PC-based products are difficult to use and lack an intrinsic voice communications path during setup
- System description
-- System allows for initiating a collaborative work-share environment without complex setup processes
-- Each party to a telephone call is provided with a collaboration button and an indicator on their telephone set
-- When the indicator is illuminated, the system is capable of establishing a work-share environment
- Implementation examples
-- System is a method and apparatus for simple spontaneous setup of a shared workspace
-- Diagrams and flowcharts illustrate the system architecture, call setup, indication of collaboration availability, and implementation of network collaboration
- Additional details
-- The system can be implemented in various ways, including using an IP-based PBX system, a common call control unit, and collaboration control programs
-- The system can be adapted for use with the Internet and non-Internet communications terminals, and can include FAX capabilities
-- The system can be deployed in a peer-to-peer architecture and can be integrated within a computer, with the telephone equipment and indicator provided by an input device of the computer.

* Design of a Downconverting Digitizer for sampling and downconverting a modulated (IF) carrier to baseband
	+ Utilizes a digitally-controlled variable gain amplifier to adjust the amplitude of the modulated IF input signal
	+ Incorporates a predictive digital filter to construct a digitally represented prediction of the modulated IF input signal
* Uses a 1-bit sampler to convert the error signal from an analog to a digital representation
	+ The sampler output contains alias components of the loop error signal
	+ The predictive structure utilizes the lowest alias component of the modulated carrier
* Implemented as a digital filter, the predictive filter is placed in the feedback path of the loop
	+ The poles of the predictive filter are placed to coincide with the center frequency of the alias component of the modulated IF after being sampled by the sampler
	+ The predictive filter is designed to generate a prediction of the modulated IF at the next sampling epoch
* The Downconverting Digitizer includes an offset nuller element to eliminate offsets from the error signal
	+ The offset nulling loop generates an estimate of these offsets and eliminates them from the error signal
	+ The offset nuller operates in conjunction with the sampler, the predictive filter, the DAC, and the analog summing element
* The predictive filter can be reprogrammed to match the modulated IF input signal
	+ The number of filter stages, weighting gain for each stage, center frequency of each filter stage, and bandwidth of each filter stage can be reprogrammed
	+ This allows the frequency response of the predictive loop to be changed upon initialization or dynamically through the use of an external algorithm
* The digital predictive loop has the inherent advantage of confining the quantization noise to a narrower bandwidth compared to conventional analog-to-digital converters
	+ This eases the design constraints placed on subsequent digital signal processing elements
	+ The dynamic frequency response adjustment feature of this invention can be used to dynamically adjust the coefficients of the predictive filter to track the instantaneous carrier frequency of the modulated IF or reduce distortion caused by interfering signals in a multi-channel receiver application
</summary>

• Sandwich panels with lattice structure cores have been developed for various applications including transportation, ballistics, blast and impact mitigation, thermal transfer, multifunctional structures, armors, load bearing, construction materials, and containers.
• The lattice structure cores can be made of hierarchical trusses, which are synergistically arranged to provide support and other functionalities.
• The hierarchical trusses can be formed by nesting an ancillary array of cells within a primary array of cells, where the ancillary array is essentially coaligned with the second order cells, the first order cells, or both the second and first order cells of the primary array.
• The primary array can be mated with a second primary array, where the first order cells of the primary arrays are oppositely oriented and essentially coaligned.
• The lattice structure cores can be manufactured using various methods, including injection molding, casting, and deposition.
• The lattice structure cores can be used in various structures, such as floors, walls, substrates, platforms, frames, housings, casings, or infrastructure.
• The structures can be associated with various systems, such as land, air, water vehicles and crafts, weapons, armor, or electronic devices and housings.
• The lattice structure cores can be used in combination with various face sheets, which can be attached or in communication with the arrays and layers of the lattice structure.
• The lattice structure cores can be designed to have specific stiffness and strength properties, making them suitable for various applications.

• Co-production process for power and hydrocarbons
• Wet and dry gasification stages for coal
• H2-enriched gas produced for hydrocarbon synthesis
• Power generated from combustion gas and synthesis gas precursor

• Wet gasification stage:
• Gasifies coal to produce combustion gas at elevated pressure
• Uses water as a carrier for solid feedstock
• Typically uses a water quench to cool the combustion gas

• Dry gasification stage:
• Gasifies coal to produce synthesis gas precursor at elevated pressure
• Uses a gas as a carrier for solid feedstock
• Typically includes a gasification stage waste heat boiler

• H2-enriched gas:
• Produced by enriching a first portion of the combustion gas with H2
• Typically obtained through water gas shift conversion
• May be purified to produce essentially pure hydrogen for hydroprocessing

• Power generation:
• Generated from a second portion of the combustion gas
• Combusted at elevated pressure in the presence of oxygen
• Recovers heat from the hot exhaust gas in a waste heat recovery stage

• The invention describes an apparatus for preparing foam sheet samples for microscopic examination.
• The apparatus includes a base structure for stabilization, a clamping arrangement to grasp the foam sheet specimen, and a screw thread specimen advance mechanism.
• The apparatus allows for precise, uniform cuts to be made on the foam sheet for microscopic examination, preserving the structure of the individual cells within the sample.

• The apparatus is designed to handle delicate foam sheet samples which are difficult to cut without damaging their cell structure.

• Operation principles of the humidity sensor:
    • The sensor's impedance decreases linearly with the relative humidity due to the combination of increased capacitance from water vapor molecules and temperature-responsive resistance.
    • The sensor's response time is almost instantaneous (1 second) due to the thin and molecularly porous dielectric and second electrode.
    • The sensor is designed for commercial humidity controls in textile mills, with a suitable range of temperatures and humidities.

• Preferred embodiment and limitations:
    • The anodized layer in the bore should be fine machined, roller burnished, and anodized with oxalic acid to achieve the desired thickness and porosity.
    • The calculated thickness of nickel deposited in the anodized layer should be between 5 and 10 Angstrom units to avoid short-circuiting the electrodes.
    • Sulfuric or nitric acid anodized layers are unsatisfactory due to residual ion-forming material, while oxalic acid gives suitable results.

• Manufacturing method:
    • The method includes anodizing the aluminum, depositing nickel particles in the anodized layer, sealing the anodized layer, and depositing a second electrode over the nickel-impregnated sealed anodized layer.
    • The anodized layer should be thoroughly rinsed and dried before depositing nickel particles.
    • The sensor should be placed in a boiling water bath to hydrolize and seal the anodized layer, and then thoroughly dried before depositing the second electrode.

• The present invention provides a method and system for generating a mobile time reference for a portable transceiver.
	• The system includes an antenna, a radio frequency subsystem, and a baseband subsystem.
	• The radio frequency subsystem includes a high frequency oscillator and a low frequency oscillator.
	• The baseband subsystem includes a free running counter coupled to the high frequency oscillator and the low frequency oscillator.
	• The free running counter provides a mobile time reference to the system and has a wake mode and a sleep mode.
	• During the wake mode, the free running counter uses the high frequency oscillator to generate the mobile time reference.
	• During the sleep mode, the free running counter uses the low frequency oscillator to maintain the mobile time reference.

<summary>

• The present invention provides a method of generating a mobile time reference.
	• The method includes providing a high frequency clock and a low frequency clock.
	• A mobile time reference is generated using the high frequency clock.
	• The mobile time reference is maintained using the low frequency clock when the high frequency clock is not available.
	• The mobile time reference is continued to be generated with the high frequency clock when the high frequency clock is again available.
	• The low frequency clock is phase locked to the high frequency clock.
	• An estimate of the drift and bias of the low frequency clock is made using a Kalman estimation.
	• The mobile time reference is updated using the cycles of the low frequency clock counted when the high frequency clock is not available and the estimated drift/bias of the low frequency clock during the step of maintaining the mobile time reference.

</summary>

- Conventional LDD structure issues:
  * Difficulty in determining the termination time for anisotropic RIE, leading to potential over-etching or under-etching of the oxide portion on the gate sidewall.
  * Inability to make the low concentration n-type region amorphous, requiring high-temperature annealing which prevents shallow junction formation and minimization of device size.
  * Hot carrier injection into the oxide film portion on the gate sidewall can cause degradation of transconductance and increased resistances in the device elements.
- Objectives of the invention:
  * Improve controllability of the width of the oxide portion on the gate sidewall.

- Methods to achieve the objectives:

  * Using an insulating layer on the gate electrode as a mask for low density region formation, followed by oxide film formation on the gate sidewall and high density region formation using this insulating film and the insulating film on the gate as a mask.
  * Using a high melting point metal or silicide as the oxide film portion on the gate sidewall for ion injection masking.
  * Forming a conductive layer or polycrystalline semiconductor layer after insulating film deposition on the gate electrode, then anisotropically etching to form the portion on the gate sidewall.
- Additional features:
  * Siliciding a desired portion of the gate electrode or the gate electrode and source/drain region in fabricating the insulated gate field effect semiconductor device having the LDD structure.

<summary>

* The invention describes a wave energy converter that harnesses energy from surface waves on a water body
* The device uses submerged containers that deform or deflect due to differences in hydrostatic pressure caused by overhead waves
* This deformation drives a hydraulic or pneumatic pump, which in turn drives a motor or turbine with an electric generator
* The device can adjust its depth to maintain high efficiency and survivability in different sea states
* The device can also increase its stroke and energy capture by using surface floating buoys and mechanical connections to surface floats.

* The device uses one or more gas tight containers submerged slightly below anticipated wave and swell troughs
* The containers are held at a fixed depth by a flexible anchoring means or a rigid sea bed attached spar or mast
* A second movable rigid end or surface opposes the first fixed end, and is connected to it by a flexible, gas tight bellows or diaphragm
* Overhead waves and troughs produce hydrostatic pressure variations that compress and expand the container, bringing the movable end closer to or further from the fixed depth end
* The relative linear motion between the fixed and movable ends is connected to a hydraulic or pneumatic pumping means or mechanical or electrical drive means

* The device can enhance its energy capture efficiency by using partial evacuation or venting of the container to increase its stroke
* It can also use pressure sensors and control valves to delay compression and expansion until hydrostatic pressure is maximized and minimized, respectively
* The device can also convert the linear oscillating motion of the container into smooth one way turbine, pump, motor or generator rotation using accumulator tanks, flow check valves, and mechanical drives

* The device can increase its energy capture and efficiency by using overhead surface floating buoys connected to the flexible reinforced bellows container
* It can also suitably shape, incline, and extend the surfaces of the moving second surface to provide major additional energy capture
* Wave reflection and focusing can also increase both potential (heave) and kinetic (surge and pitch) wave energy capture

* The device can have a typical diameter and stroke of 5-10 meters and produce 0.25 MW to 1 MW of electrical power
* Elongated or multi-unit devices

- The invention aims to improve the avoidance of disruptions in the cigarette magazine of a cigarette-production and/or cigarette-packaging machine.
- A detection process is proposed, which uses at least one optical checking element to scan and evaluate images of cigarettes in the magazine. If the scanned image deviates from a reference image or reference value, an error signal is produced.
- A detection apparatus is also proposed, consisting of an optical checking element, an image-processing device, and means to produce an error signal when the scanned image deviates from the reference.
- The process and apparatus offer the advantage of monitoring a larger area of cigarettes, providing an overview of their orientation and enabling the detection of transversely located cigarettes.
- The system can also register defective cigarettes, such as those missing a filter or bent/broken ones.
- A disruption detected can be eliminated manually or automatically, with the error signal being emitted acoustically or optically to alert the operator.
- An elimination process is proposed, which detects a defective/incorrectly positioned cigarette and actuates an ejecting unit to remove a plurality of cigarettes from the magazine.
- An elimination apparatus is also proposed, consisting of at least one ejecting unit arranged in the region of the magazine, capable of ejecting a plurality of cigarettes located in an ejecting zone assigned to the ejecting unit.
- Multiple adjacent ejecting zones and units are preferred, allowing for targeted ejection without affecting the entire width of the cigarette magazine.

* **Pre-September 11 Aviation Security Vulnerabilities:**

	+ Inadequate access controls at airports
	+ Unprotected air traffic control computer systems
* **Government Recommendations and Implementation:**
	+ Multiple recommendations made to the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA)
	+ FAA implemented some recommendations, but progress was slow
	+ Aviation and Transportation Security Act (ATSA) established Transportation Security Administration (TSA) and shifted security-screening responsibilities from airlines to TSA
* **ATSA Mandates:**
	+ Federal screeners at 429 commercial airports by November 19, 2002
	+ Explosives detection technology at airports by December 31, 2002
	+ Some aviation security responsibilities remained with FAA, such as air traffic control and facility security
* **TSA and FAA Actions since September 11:**
	+ TSA implemented congressional mandates and explored technology options
	+ FAA focused on enhancing the security of air traffic control systems and facilities
* **TSA's First Year:**
	+ Established organization and focused on meeting aviation security deadlines
	+ Grew from 13 employees in January 2002 to about 65,000 employees in January 2003
	+ Met over 30 deadlines during 2002
* **Challenges and Concerns:**
	+ Operational and management control problems emerged in the Federal Air Marshal Service
	+ Delays in deploying explosives detection systems
	+ Concerns about travelers' privacy rights with CAPPS II
* **TSA Initiatives:**
	+ Developing a Transportation Workers Identification Card (TWIC) program
	+ Exploring a registered traveler program for low-risk passengers
* **Additional Aviation Security Issues:**
	+ Vulnerabilities in air cargo, general aviation, and airport perimeter security
	+ Legislative proposals to address potential vulnerabilities and other aviation security issues

* LDA, IRC section 4911, and IRC section 162(e) have different definitions of lobbying
	+ LDA covers contacts with federal officials only
	+ IRC section 4911 covers contacts with state and local government officials to influence state and local legislation
	+ IRC section 162(e) provides an exception for contacts with local legislative officials regarding legislation of direct interest to the organization
* LDA covers grassroots lobbying, such as television commercials, newspaper advertisements, and direct mail campaigns to influence federal, state, and local legislation
	+ IRC section 4911 and IRC section 162(e) also cover grassroots lobbying
* LDA defines covered officials differently depending on whether the subject of the lobbying contact is legislative or nonlegislative
	+ When the subject of a lobbyist's contact concerns a nonlegislative matter, such as a regulation, grant, or contract, LDA covers more officials than the IRC definitions cover
	+ When the subject of a lobbyist's contact is a legislative matter, both IRC definitions potentially cover more levels of executive branch officials than the LDA definition does
* LDA covers contacts with all Members of Congress and employees of Congress and approximately 4,600 executive branch officials for either legislative or nonlegislative subjects
	+ IRC section 4911 covers contacts with legislative or executive branch officials, including Members of Congress and the President, about any nonlegislative subject, but contacts with nonlegislative subjects do not count as lobbying
	+ IRC section 162(e) covers very few executive branch officials if contacts are about nonlegislative matters
* LDA contains 19 exceptions to the definition of lobbying, while IRC section 162(e) has one exception and IRC section 4911 has five exceptions
	+ Two of the exceptions under IRC section 4911 could allow a significant amount of lobbying expenses to be excluded from coverage
* The choice of definition can significantly affect whether an organization must register with the Secretary of the Senate and the Clerk of the House of Representatives and what information they must disclose on their semiannual lobbying reports

- Current surface transportation programs are not effective at addressing key challenges, such as increasing congestion and growing freight demand, due to unclear federal goals and lack of links to needs or performance.
  * Many programs have numerous and sometimes conflicting goals, with only one federal program specifically directed at intermodal infrastructure.
  * Most highway, transit, and safety grant funds are distributed through formulas that have only an indirect relationship to needs and many have no relationship to performance or outcomes.
- Surface transportation programs often do not employ the best tools and approaches to ensure effective investment decisions.
  * Rigorous economic analysis does not generally drive the investment decisions of state and local governments.
  * The federal government also does not possess adequate data to assess outcomes or implement performance measures.
- The solvency of the federal surface transportation program is at risk because expenditures now exceed revenues for the Highway Trust Fund.
  * The current fuel tax of 18.4 cents per gallon has been in place since 1993, and the buying power of the fixed cents-per-gallon amount has since been eroded by inflation.
  * The reallocation to the Highway Trust Fund of 4.3 cents of federal fuel tax previously dedicated to deficit reduction provided an influx of funds beginning in 1997, but this influx has been insufficient to sustain current spending levels.
- A reexamination of the federal approach to surface transportation problems and a restructuring of federal programs to create more focused, performance-based, and sustainable programs is needed.
  * Identifying areas of national interest is an important first step in any proposal to restructure and fund surface transportation programs.
  * Proposals should also clarify specific goals for federal involvement in surface transportation programs and define the federal role in relation to the roles of state and local governments, regional entities, and the private sector.

• Superfund Program and Incineration as a Cleanup Remedy
	• The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) established the Superfund program to clean up the nation's most severely contaminated hazardous waste sites.
	• EPA uses incineration as a Superfund cleanup remedy, which involves burning substances in a controlled flame in an enclosed area to convert contamination into residual products.
	• As of October 1996, EPA planned to use incineration at four additional sites, and it had selected incineration as a remedy in about 6% of its decisions.

• Regulations, Standards, and Monitoring for Incineration at Superfund Sites
	• Fixed facility hazardous waste incinerators are required by the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act of 1976 (RCRA) to obtain an operating permit from EPA and meet RCRA's substantive requirements.
	• EPA requires incinerators at Superfund sites to meet RCRA's emissions standards and establishes specific cleanup standards for each incinerator used at a Superfund site.
	• EPA relies on four principal methods to ensure the safe operation of incinerators used to clean up Superfund sites, including setting site-specific standards, incorporating safety features, monitoring emissions, and providing 24-hour on-site oversight.
	• EPA continuously monitors the air in the vicinity of an incinerator to ensure that emissions do not exceed the maximum permitted levels and uses air monitors and laboratory analyses to measure conditions and detect possible emissions.

• Military Working Dogs (MWDs):
   • Definition: Any canine bred, procured, or acquired to meet DOD’s requirements for operations in the protection of installations, resources, and personnel.
   • Disposition: MWDs are removed from service when they can no longer perform their duties due to medical or behavior problems, when they are no longer needed by the military, or in other circumstances.

• Adoption of MWDs:
   • Robby’s Law: Promotes the adoption of MWDs after their military service, giving first priority to former handlers, then to others capable of humanely caring for the MWD, and finally to law enforcement agencies.
   • Veterinary Expenses: After adoption, the United States is not liable for any veterinary expense associated with the adopted MWD for a condition of the military animal before transfer. DOD is authorized to establish and maintain a veterinary care system for adopted MWDs, but no federal funds may be used for this purpose.

- **Medicare payments for ambulance services**
	+ Consist of two components: a service-level payment for the type of transport and a mileage payment

	+ Providers may be for-profit, nonprofit, or government-based

- **Costs and revenue sources of ambulance providers**
	+ Costs and revenues vary depending on the resources available in communities and communities’ choices about funding
	+ Revenue sources may include community tax support, charitable donations, in-kind contributions, state and federal grants, subscription programs, payments from Medicare or Medicaid, and private health insurance companies
	+ Medicare pays ambulance providers through a national fee schedule
	+ Providers paid under a fee schedule generally have an incentive to keep their costs to deliver services at or below the fee schedule rate
- **Variation in costs per transport**
	+ Costs per transport vary widely, ranging from $224 to $2,204 in 2010
	+ Factors contributing to cost variation include volume of transports, intensity of Medicare transports, and level of government subsidies received
	+ Super-rural providers had significantly higher estimated median costs per transport than urban providers
	+ When controlling for other provider characteristics, differences in cost per transport by service area were not significant
- **Medicare margins for ambulance providers**
	+ The median Medicare margin, including add-on payments, was about positive 2 percent in 2010 for the providers in the sample
	+ When add-on payments were removed, payments decreased, resulting in a lower median Medicare margin of negative 1 percent for those providers
	+ Both the 2007 and current studies showed wide variation in costs per transport and Medicare margins, despite differences in samples and measures used for reporting Medicare margins

• SSA's disclosure policy for law enforcement is restrictive relative to most other federal agencies, but similar to IRS and Census due to restrictive disclosure requirements outlined in their statutes.
	• SSA's disclosure policy allows the disclosure of information to law enforcement under certain conditions, requiring SSA officials to consider several factors before releasing individuals' personal information.
	• SSA's disclosure policy is designed to protect the privacy rights of individuals to the fullest extent possible while permitting the exchange of records required to fulfill its administrative and program responsibilities.
	• The Privacy Act of 1974 is the primary law governing the protection of personal privacy by agencies of the federal government, regulating the collection, maintenance, use, and disclosure of personal information that federal agencies maintain in a system of records.
	• SSA's disclosure policy has been revised to comply with about 25 statutes, including the Privacy Act, and requires agencies to inform individuals of the authority for the collection, the principal purpose for the collection of information, what the routine uses for the information may be, and what the consequences are of not providing the information.
	• SSA's disclosure policy permits the sharing of nontax information with law enforcement, but only under certain conditions, and is more restrictive than both the law enforcement exception specified under the Privacy Act and the disclosure policies of most federal agencies.

	• Waste associated with cleanups, often referred to as remediation waste, must be managed under RCRA if it contains a hazardous component

	• EPA plans to issue regulations covering four specific elements affecting remediation waste
	• EPA and state cleanup managers have identified three RCRA requirements that create disincentives for industry to clean up previously contaminated sites: land disposal restrictions, minimum technological requirements, and requirements for permits.

• The Internet's domain name system (DNS) is a critical resource for American businesses and consumers, supporting hundreds of billions of dollars of commerce each year and vital services such as power distribution, health care, law enforcement, and national defense.
• The DNS relies on a set of functions, including the root servers, to ensure the uniqueness of each e-mail and Web site address. The U.S. government supported the implementation of the DNS for nearly a decade.
• In 1998, the Department of Commerce began a process to transition the technical responsibility for the DNS to the private sector, issuing a general statement of policy known as the "White Paper."
• ICANN, a not-for-profit organization, was established to guide the transition and has made significant progress in increasing competition, but progress has been slower on activities designed to address stability, security, representation, and coordination.
• In early 2002, ICANN's president concluded that ICANN faced serious problems and established an internal committee to recommend options for reform.
• Several efforts to address the White Paper's guiding principle for improving the security and stability of the Internet are behind schedule, including developing operational requirements and security policies for the root servers and formalizing relationships with other entities involved in running the DNS.

* History of federal trust fund management for Indian tribes
	+ Funds held in trust since 1820
	+ General Allotment Act of 1887 provided for division of tribal lands into individual allotments
	+ Indian Reorganization Act of 1934 ended allotment of tribal lands and extended trust period indefinitely
	+ Many allotments remain in trust today, jointly owned by hundreds or thousands of individual Indians with fractionated interests
* Role of the Secretary of the Interior and the Bureau of Indian Affairs (BIA)
	+ Secretary is trustee for tribes and Indians, responsible for accounting for revenue, investing trust funds, maintaining official land title and ownership records, managing natural resource assets, and probating estates
	+ BIA has 12 regional and 85 agency offices located on or near reservations
* Trust reform efforts
	+ Beginning in April 1997, Interior has issued several strategic plans for implementing trust reforms
	+ Comprehensive Trust Management Plan issued in March 2003 to guide design and implementation of integrated trust reform efforts
	+ Fiduciary Trust Model contains implementation strategies for major business processes and serves as guide for trust reform
* Trust reform contract with Electronic Data Systems in 2001
	+ Recommendations included improvements in trust management and reorganization of Interior's agencies carrying out trust management
	+ Secretary reorganized BIA and Office of Special Trustee (OST) in April 2003
* OST's budget and staff
	+ Budget has grown from $34.1 million in fiscal year 1997 to $222.8 million in fiscal year 2006
	+ Full-time equivalent positions have increased from 245 employees in fiscal year 1997 to 590 employees in fiscal year 2006

• IRS uses the Examination Quality Measurement System (EQMS) to measure the quality of closed audits against nine IRS audit standards.
• Each standard includes additional key elements describing specific components of a quality audit.
• The audit workpaper standard requires that workpapers provide the principal support for the auditor’s report and document the procedures applied, tests performed, information obtained, and conclusions reached.
• The five key elements for this workpaper standard involve fully disclosing the audit trail and techniques used, clear and concise documentation, accurate tax adjustments, adequate documentation of the audit activity records, and protection of taxpayers’ rights to privacy and confidentiality.
• IRS has historically found problems with the quality of its workpapers, with IRS auditors meeting all of the key elements of the workpaper standard in no more than 72 percent of the audits during the past 6 years.
• Workpapers are an important part of the audit effort, used to formulate and document the auditor’s findings, conclusions, and recommended adjustments, and to make decisions about how much additional tax is owed by the taxpayer.
• IRS’ primary quality control mechanism is supervisory review of the audit workpapers to ensure adherence to the audit standards.
• However, IRS group managers’ reviews of the audit workpapers during the audits to help ensure that the recommended tax adjustments are supported and verified, and that the audits do not unnecessarily burden the audited taxpayers are not always documented.
• IRS is currently drafting changes to the IRM relating to workpapers, requiring managers to document managerial involvement.
• The GAO recommends that the IRS Commissioner require audit supervisors to document their review of audit workpapers as a control over the quality of audits and the associated workpapers.

* Bankruptcy process for financial companies
	+ Two approaches: judicial bankruptcy process or special legal and regulatory resolution regimes
	+ Bankruptcy is a federal court procedure to help individuals and businesses eliminate or restructure debts
	+ Filing of a bankruptcy petition operates as an automatic stay, stopping most lawsuits and collection activities
	+ Equitable treatment of creditors means similar claims are classified similarly and receive the same treatment
	+ Business debtors may seek liquidation or reorganization
	+ Proceedings can be voluntary or involuntary, with the debtor able to defend against involuntary proceedings
	+ Chapter 7 involves court-supervised liquidation of the debtor's assets, while Chapter 11 allows for reorganization

* Resolution regimes for insolvent financial entities
	+ Created to address insolvent financial entities such as insured depository institutions and insurance companies
	+ Goal is to resolve insolvent financial entities in an orderly and efficient manner, protecting depositors and other creditors
	+ Examples include the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) for insured depository institutions and the Federal Housing Finance Agency (FHFA) for government-sponsored enterprises
	+ These resolution regimes have the authority to take control of and resolve failing financial entities, often through the sale of the entity's assets or the creation of a bridge institution

* Treatment of qualified financial contracts (QFCs) in bankruptcy
	+ QFCs include derivative financial products and repurchase agreements
	+ Safe harbor provisions in the Bankruptcy Code allow nondefaulting counterparties to exercise certain contractual rights, even if doing so would otherwise violate the automatic stay
	+ This can include liquidating, terminating, or accelerating the contract and offsetting any termination value, payment amount, or other transfer obligation
	+ The goal is to limit market turmoil and prevent the insolvency of one firm from spreading to other firms

* Orderly Liquidation Authority (OLA) under the Dodd-Frank Act
	+ Allows the FDIC to resolve large financial companies outside of the bankruptcy process
	+ Applies to bank holding companies or nonbank financial companies designated for supervision by the Federal Reserve

* The baby boomer generation (persons born between 1946 and 1964) will start turning 65 in 2011 and the last will turn 65 in 2029.
	+ This will lead to significant changes in the ratio of the working age population to the population age 65 or older, known as the "aged dependency ratio."
	+ The aged dependency ratio was 21% in 2000, but will rise to 35% by 2030, meaning there will be fewer than three persons of traditional working age for every person age 65 or over.
* The increase in the aged dependency ratio is not only due to the growing numbers of older persons, but also the slowing growth of the labor force of younger workers.
	+ From 1950 to 1990, the labor force under 55 grew at an average annual rate of 1.9%, but from 1990 to 2000, the average annual growth rate for this group was 1.0%.
	+ The BLS projects that from 2000 to 2025, labor force growth will slow to an annual rate of 0.3%.

<summary>

* **Visa Waiver Program (VWP)**: Established in 1986, the VWP allows visa-free travel to the United States for eligible citizens from 36 participating countries. The program aims to facilitate legitimate travel for business or tourism, boost international business and tourism, and create economic benefits.
* **ESTA Implementation**: In 2008, DHS implemented the Electronic System for Travel Authorization (ESTA) to electronically collect biographical information and responses to eligibility questions from VWP applicants. ESTA approval is generally valid for 2 years, and passengers no longer need to complete the I-94W form for most air and sea travel.
* **Carrier Compliance and ESTA Fees**: Carriers must verify ESTA approval for passengers before boarding them, and DHS began enforcing compliance in March 2010. However, DHS has not fully analyzed the risks of carrier and passenger noncompliance with the ESTA requirement. Additionally, a $14 fee was introduced in 2010, which includes $10 for the creation of a corporation to promote travel to the United States and $4 to fund ESTA operations.
* **Information Sharing Agreements**: The 9/11 Act requires VWP countries to enter into agreements with the United States to share information regarding whether citizens and nationals traveling to the United States represent a threat to the security or welfare of the United States and to report lost or stolen passports. However, only half of the countries have entered into all required agreements, and many of the agreements entered into have not been implemented.
* **DHS Oversight and Reporting**: DHS conducts reviews to determine whether issues of security, law enforcement, or immigration affect VWP country participation in the program. However, DHS has not completed half of the mandated biennial reports resulting from these reviews in a timely manner. Additionally, DHS has not consistently submitted VWP country biennial reports in a timely manner since the legal requirement was imposed in 2002, which affects Congress's ability to ensure that DHS efforts to require program countries to minimize vulnerabilities and its recommendations for continued status in the VWP are based on up-to-date assessments.
</summary>

• Federal law and state child welfare systems play crucial roles in protecting children and providing them with permanent homes.
	• Over the past decade, growing caseloads have strained the ability of state child welfare systems to keep pace with the needs of troubled children and their families.
	• The Adoption Assistance and Child Welfare Act of 1980 requires states to make reasonable efforts to prevent or eliminate the need for removing children from their homes and to provide services to families and children with the goal of reuniting them.
	• If reunification is not possible, the state is required to find permanent placement for the child outside the family home, with options including reuniting the child with his or her family, placing the child for adoption, or continuing temporary or permanent foster care.
	• To expedite the permanency planning process, 26 states have enacted laws or policies to shorten the time between entering foster care and the first permanency hearing, with most requiring the hearing within 12 months.
	• States have implemented various operational and procedural changes to expedite and improve the permanency process, including low-cost, creative methods for financing and providing services that address specific barriers to reuniting families.
	• Developing and successfully implementing initiatives to move children from foster care into permanent placements more quickly requires local leadership involvement, consensus building, and sustained resources, but can also create unintended consequences if not properly managed.

• FSA manages and administers student financial assistance programs under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965, providing more than $50 billion in aid annually to approximately 8 million students and their families
	• In 1998, Congress established FSA as a Performance-Based Organization (PBO) to improve service, reduce costs, increase accountability, provide greater flexibility, integrate information systems, implement a common delivery system, and ensure program integrity
	• FSA has developed a performance plan and implemented a balanced scorecard to link employees' day-to-day activities with the organization's strategic goals, but has faced challenges in connecting scorecard results to individual work and reporting annually to Congress on its progress
	• FSA's unit cost measure, used to demonstrate how it is reducing the cost of administering student aid programs, has limitations and does not include all program obligations, making it less useful to congressional decision makers
	• FSA's performance plan has limitations in addressing systems integration and program integrity, and it has been difficult to discern whether changes in the unit cost measure are indicative of changes in total program costs
	• FSA has developed strategies to improve schools' regulatory compliance and enhance program integrity, but it is not clear how FSA will know whether its strategies are effective or how it will define measurable outcomes for program integrity
	• FSA has taken steps to adopt sound human capital principles, but has not yet implemented a performance management system and has faced challenges in planning for the succession, deployment, and training of staff.

<summary>

* Transit-Oriented Development (TOD): Generally defined as compact, mixed-use, walkable neighborhoods located near transit, usually within half a mile of a transit station. TODs can vary in size and scope, and can be found in urban centers or suburban neighborhoods.
* Benefits of TOD: Increased access to opportunities, promotion of transportation options, increased transit ridership, reduced road congestion.
* Stakeholders: Local transit agencies, state and local departments of transportation, metropolitan-planning organizations, local governments, regional councils, private developers, lenders, business improvement districts.
* Federal Transit Administration (FTA) and TOD: FTA provides funds for transit projects that may spur TOD, but does not have a discrete program for TOD. However, FTA has been expanding its role in TOD in recent years through research, coordination with other agencies, and a transit-oriented development planning pilot program.
* Factors Supporting TOD: Market demand for real estate, available land for development, supportive local residents, efficient transit access to job and activity centers.
* Factors Hindering TOD: Higher construction costs, lenders' reluctance to finance TOD, lengthy local-development approval processes, unsupportive local population, undesirable physical features surrounding a transit station, unsupportive land uses.
* Local Government Policies to Encourage TOD: Zoning regulations, station area planning, targeted infrastructure investments, and tax incentives that align with local residents' preferences and market demand for development.
* FTA Evaluation of TOD for New Starts Funding: FTA evaluates proposed projects for New Starts funding according to criteria including mobility improvements, environmental benefits, congestion relief, economic development effects, land use, and cost-effectiveness. Two of these criteria, economic development effects and land use, require documentation from project sponsors related to whether current and future land use is supportive of transit.
</summary>

- The Social Security Administration (SSA) sends Personal Earnings and Benefit Estimate Statements (PEBES) to workers to inform them about their Social Security benefits and to encourage them to review their earnings records for accuracy.
* The PEBES includes estimates of retirement, disability, and survivor benefits.
* The PEBES also shows the worker's earnings history and the amount of taxes paid into the Social Security system.
* The PEBES is mailed to workers who are 25 and older and have earned at least four credits in the past two years.
* Fewer than 2% of workers request a PEBES each year.
* The PEBES legislation requires SSA to begin sending the PEBES to eligible workers who have not requested a statement.
* SSA plans to mail statements to over 70 million workers by fiscal year 2000.
* The goals of the PEBES are to inform the public about benefits available under SSA's programs, assist workers in planning for their financial future, and ensure that Social Security earnings records are complete and accurate.
* Accurate earnings records are important because a worker's eligibility for Social Security benefits and the size of the benefit depend on the worker's earnings record.
* Early identification and correction of errors in earnings records can benefit both SSA and the public by reducing the time and cost required to correct earnings records years later when an individual files for retirement benefits.

- The PEBES is a significant initiative for SSA, with a projected cost of $80 million in fiscal year 2000.
* The cost includes $56 million for production costs, such as printing and mailing the statement, and $24 million for personnel costs.
* SSA estimates that 608 staff-years will be required to handle the PEBES workload in fiscal year 2000.
* SSA staff are needed to prepare the statements, investigate discrepancies in workers' earnings records, and respond to public inquiries.

- The benefit estimates provided in the PEBES are intended to help workers plan for their financial future.
* To estimate retirement benefits, SSA makes certain assumptions about an individual's future employment and earnings.
* SSA assumes, for example, that individuals will continue to work until they retire and that individuals' future earnings

		• Same definition of disability for initial entitlement

<summary>

* **Hurricane Katrina relief efforts:** The Stafford Act authorizes the federal government to assist in saving lives, reducing human suffering, mitigating the effects of lost income, and helping repair or rebuild certain damaged facilities. As of June 2006, nearly $88 billion was appropriated by the Congress for relief and recovery efforts related to the recent Gulf Coast hurricanes.
	+ **FEMA's role:** FEMA, the DHS component statutorily charged with administering the provisions of the Stafford Act, uses appropriations made to the Stafford Act’s Disaster Relief Fund to assist relief and recovery efforts.
	+ **Mission assignments:** FEMA has authority under the Stafford Act to issue an order, called a mission assignment, to other federal agencies. A mission assignment is a tasking issued by FEMA that directs other federal agencies and components of DHS to support overall federal operations pursuant to, or in anticipation of, a Stafford Act declaration.
	+ **Funding and reimbursement process:** Once the mission assignment is issued and approved, the mission assignment document is FEMA’s basis for obligating the portion of FEMA’s funds allocated to the assigned relief and recovery effort. From a federal agency standpoint, the mission assignment provides the recipient agency reimbursable budgetary authority, not the actual transfer of funds, to perform the agreed upon work.
* **Tracking and reporting issues:** The federal government is not adequately tracking and reporting on the use of the $88 billion in hurricane relief and recovery funds provided thus far to 23 federal agencies in the four emergency supplemental appropriations acts.
	+ **FEMA's limitations:** FEMA does not have mechanisms in place to collect and report on information from the other agencies that are performing work on its behalf through mission assignments.
	+ **Lack of a governmentwide framework:** Although each federal agency is responsible for tracking the funds it received, obligations incurred, and funds expended through it own internal tracking systems, no mechanisms are in place to consolidate this information.
	+ **Inaccurate reporting:** FEMA records the entire amount upfront as an obligation on its reports to the Congress when it tasks another agency through a mission assignment, while the agency performing the task for FEMA does not record an obligation until a later date

	+ * Financial transactions could be delayed, flights grounded, power lost, and national defense affected

	+ * Information and telecommunications; banking and finance; health, safety, and emergency services; transportation; power and water; and manufacturing and small business
	+ * Telecommunications sector is especially important
	+ * Global nature of the problem poses additional risks
- * Disruptions if Y2K problem is not corrected
	+ * Grounded or delayed flights, degraded safety, customer inconvenience, and increased airline costs
	+ * Aircraft and other military equipment could be grounded
	+ * Medical devices and scientific laboratory equipment may experience problems
- * Federal government's challenge
	+ * Many federal government's computer systems are poorly documented and use obsolete computer languages
	+ * Each line of code must be examined for date-format problems
	+ * Federal government depends on the telecommunications infrastructure to deliver a wide range of services

	+ * 40% of the mission-critical systems were compliant in May 1998
	+ * Substantial number of mission-critical systems will not be compliant in time
- * Uneven progress among federal agencies

	+ * Other agencies have made progress but risks continue

- * Additional vulnerabilities and recommendations

	+ * Business continuity and contingency planning across the government has been inadequate
	+ * OMB's assessment of the current status of federal Year 2000 progress is predominantly based on agency reports that have not been consistently reviewed or verified

- * Mutual funds and banks as financial intermediaries
	+ Mutual funds invest in securities (bonds and stocks)
	+ Banks invest in loans and debt securities (primarily government bonds)
	+ Both channel funds from savers to the economy
- * Decline in bank loans as a source of finance
	+ Large businesses replacing bank loans with commercial paper since the 1960s
	+ Household sector becoming less dependent on bank loans
	+ Securitization of mortgages, credit card debt, and automobile loans
- * Impact of mutual funds on deposits
	+ Mutual funds attracting sizable amounts of money that might have been placed in bank deposits
	+ Difficulty in quantifying the full impact of mutual funds on deposits
	+ Estimated impact of mutual funds on deposits: less than $700 billion (1990-1994)
- * Shift from deposits to mutual funds
	+ Low interest rates on bank deposits compared to expected risk-adjusted returns on mutual fund investments
	+ Potential reversal of movement from deposits to mutual funds if gap between deposit rates of return and expected mutual fund rates of return narrows
- * Effect on total supply of loanable and investable funds
	+ Little if any effect on the total supply of loanable and investable funds available to the economy
	+ Shift in intermediaries through which finance flows
- * Impact on borrowers
	+ Mutual funds investing mainly in securities, which might increase access to finance for those who issue securities
	+ Difficulty in measuring the extent to which this has occurred from statistical information available
	+ All three sectors (residential, consumer, and business) increasing access to finance raised in the securities markets
- * Securitization of residential finance
	+ Most residential mortgages written in a way to facilitate securitization
	+ Banks and thrifts providing indirect financing to homeowners through mortgage-backed securities
- * Securitization of consumer credit
	+ Banks and other providers of consumer finance securitizing some of their automobile loans and credit card receivables
	+ Consumers obtaining indirect access to the securities markets through finance companies that borrow from the securities markets and lend to consumers

- **Refugee Resettlement in the United States**
	+ The U.S. government provides financial support to partially cover resettlement services based on a fixed per capita sum per refugee.
	+ Services include arranging for refugees' placement and providing them with basic necessities and core services during their initial resettlement period.
	+ Reimburses states and alternative refugee assistance programs for the cost of cash and medical assistance provided to refugees during the first 8 months after their arrival in this country or grant of asylum.
- **Integration of Refugees**
	+ The integration of refugees into the United States is a complex process associated with various factors, including pre- and post-migration experiences, gender, class, ethnic differences, and access to resources.
	+ Federal agencies, such as the Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR) and the Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration (PRM), have efforts to define, measure, or facilitate refugees' integration into the United States.
	+ ORR's annual reports to Congress and the ORR integration working group's 2007 interim report provide information on refugee integration.
- **Secondary Migration of Refugees**
	+ Secondary migration of refugees refers to the movement of refugees from one community to another after initial resettlement.
	+ ORR collects secondary migration data annually from each state but does not collect community-level data.
	+ PRM collects data from local voluntary agencies regarding the number of refugees who move away from a community within the first 90 days after arrival but does not collect data on the estimated number of refugees who enter the community during the same time period.

- The National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) was established in 1968 to provide flood insurance and reduce the federal government's costs for repairing flood damage after disasters.
	+ NFIP is overseen by the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) and has mapped flood risks across the country, assigning flood zone designations based on risk levels.
	+ Communities participate in NFIP by enforcing regulations for land use and new construction in high-risk flood zones and adopting floodplain management regulations.
- NFIP offers two types of flood insurance premiums: subsidized and full risk.
	+ Subsidized premium rates, which are about 40 to 45 percent of the cost of covering the full risk of flood damage, apply to about 22 percent of all NFIP policies.
	+ To help reduce or eliminate the long-term risk of flood damage, FEMA has used mitigation efforts such as elevation, relocation, and demolition.
- However, the inventories of repetitive loss properties and policies with subsidized premium rates have continued to grow.
	+ Repetitive loss properties are generally defined as those that have had two or more flood insurance claims payments of $1,000 or more over 10 years.
	+ Owners of these properties who do not mitigate may face higher premiums.
- NFIP currently does not charge all program participants rates that reflect the full risk of flooding to their properties.
	+ FEMA is required to charge many policyholders less than full-risk rates to encourage program participation.
	+ FEMA may "grandfather" properties that are already in the program when new flood maps place them in higher-risk zones.
- Increasing premium rates to fully reflect the risk of loss would have several advantages.
	+ It could result in premium rates that more fully reflected the actual risk of loss.
	+ It could decrease costs for taxpayers by reducing costs associated with postdisaster borrowing to pay claims.
	+ It could encourage private market participation, because the rates would more closely approximate those that would be charged by private insurers.
- A variety of actions could be taken to mitigate the disadvantages of increasing premium rates.
	+ Subsidized rates could be phased out over time or not transferred with the property

* **287(g) program authorization and responsibilities**
	+ Authorizes ICE to enter into agreements with state/local law enforcement agencies for certain functions related to investigation, apprehension, or detention of aliens
	+ Allows state/local officers to communicate with ICE regarding immigration status and cooperate in identification/removal of aliens not lawfully present
	+ Officers have direct access to ICE databases, process aliens for removal, initiate removal proceedings, and transport aliens to detention facilities
	+ ICE has discretion to establish enforcement priorities for the program
	+ Detailed requirements for the program include written agreements, officer qualifications, federal law knowledge, training, supervision, and specific powers/duties

* **ICE’s Office of State and Local Coordination (OSLC)**
	+ Responsible for providing information about ICE programs, initiatives, and authorities available to state/local law enforcement agencies
	+ Organized various programs to partner with state/local law enforcement agencies as Agreements of Cooperation in Communities to Enhance Safety and Security (ACCESS)
	+ ACCESS offers state/local agencies opportunity to participate in 1 or more of 13 programs, including 287(g) program
	+ OSLC officials work with applicants to help determine which assistance program would best meet their needs

* **287(g) program models**
	+ Jail model: correctional officers in state prisons/local jails screen those arrested/convicted of crimes to ascertain immigration status
	+ Task force model: law enforcement officers in criminal task forces screen arrested individuals using federal databases to assess immigration status
	+ Joint model: local law enforcement agencies concurrently implement both models

* **Rapid growth and support for 287(g) program**
	+ Program has grown rapidly in recent years
	+ Viewed by members of Congress as opportunity to provide ICE with more resources to assist in enforcement of immigration laws
	+ DHS appropriations acts expressly provided funds for the program since fiscal year 2006
	+ Accompanying committee reports emphasized close monitoring of compliance, extensive training, direct supervision, and enrollment of correctional facilities

		+ Division of Investment Management reviews disclosure documents and engages in rulemaking, exemption determination, and legal interpretations

	* SEC regulates mutual funds under various acts and rules
		+ Investment Company Act of 1940: specifically regulates mutual funds and other investment companies, requires registration with SEC, and imposes operational and structural requirements
		+ Investment Advisers Act of 1940: requires mutual fund advisers to register with SEC, imposes reporting requirements, and prohibits fraudulent practices
		+ Securities Act of 1933: requires registration of fund shares offered to the public and regulates mutual fund advertising
		+ Securities Exchange Act of 1934: regulates how funds are sold and requires registration of persons distributing funds or executing fund transactions
	* SROs such as NASD and NYSE regulate broker-dealers, including their mutual fund sales practices

	* Historically, routine examinations of mutual fund complexes have been the cornerstone of SEC's mutual fund oversight
		+ Routine examinations accounted for 85% of total fund examinations from 1998 through 2003
		+ SEC generally tried to examine each complex at least once every 5 years
		+ Resource constraints led to targeted examinations focusing on discrete areas with high risks of compliance problems
	* SEC has implemented a revised approach to conducting routine examinations
		+ Systematic process for documenting and assess

• TVA is an independent federal corporation established by the TVA Act to improve the quality of life in the Tennessee River Valley through various means, including building dams and hydropower facilities.
	• In 1959, Congress amended the TVA Act to provide TVA with the authority to finance its power program through revenue from electricity sales and borrowing, and required it to repay a substantial portion of the annual appropriations it had received.
	• TVA's board, nominated by the President and confirmed by the U.S. Senate, sets TVA’s goals and policies, appoints the CEO, develops long-range plans, and approves TVA’s budget and rate changes.
	• TVA's most recent strategic plan covers fiscal years 2014 through 2018 and outlines its strategic imperatives, including maintaining low rates, living within its means, managing assets to meet reliability expectations and provide a balanced portfolio, and being responsible stewards of the region’s natural resources.
	• TVA plans to reduce its debt to about $22 billion by fiscal year 2023 through increasing revenue, limiting the growth of operating expenses, and reducing capital expenditures.
	• TVA uses a 10-year long-range financial plan to determine the amount of funds that will be available for capital investment, and operating priorities are detailed in business unit plans.
	• TVA has expanded beyond hydropower to other types of power generation such as natural gas, coal, and nuclear plants, and periodically develops an integrated resource plan to guide decisions about the resources needed to meet future demand for electricity.
	• TVA's financial condition worsened in the late 1960s and 1970s due to construction delays, cost overruns, and operational shutdowns in its nuclear program, and the agency continues to invest in nuclear projects while deferring full recognition and funding of pension liabilities.
	• TVA's unfunded pension liabilities affect its financial health and operations, and without better documentation and communication of TVA’s goals to reduce debt and unfunded pension liabilities in its performance plan and report, congressional and other stakeholders will not have a complete picture of TVA’s progress toward managing its debt or its overall financial health.

* First City Bancorporation of Texas, a bank holding company, received open bank assistance from the FDIC in 1988 due to its high concentration of loans to the energy industry in the Southwest United States and the financial difficulties of the energy industry in the early and mid-1980s.
	
	* The open bank assistance included a $970 million capital infusion from the FDIC and $500 million of private capital raised by the new bank management. The FDIC received $970 million in preferred stock of a collecting bank and a guarantee for $100 million payable in 1998 towards the retirement of the collecting bank preferred stock.
	
	* Despite the recapitalization, the First City banks continued to engage in high-risk lending practices and experienced problems with the quality of their loan portfolios. By September 1990, the banks reported $183 million in profits and paid $122 million in cash dividends, but by September 1992, the banks incurred total losses of about $625 million and both the OCC and FRS projected the insolvency of the Houston and Dallas banks by the end of 1992.
	
	* The FDIC, OCC, and the Texas Banking Commissioner closely monitored the First City banks following the recapitalization and considered various resolution plans, including a Type A transaction (acquisition by a stronger institution), a Type B transaction (major capital infusion by an outside investor), and a Type C transaction (self-rescue by the banking organization).
	
	* Ultimately, the FDIC rejected a Type A transaction for open bank assistance due to its estimated cost of $240 million, which was higher than the FDIC's estimate of $179 million to liquidate the banks. The FDIC also rejected First City's self-rescue proposals due to concerns about the ability of First City bank management to execute the proposals and the estimated $200 million capital shortfall at the reconstituted banks.
	
	* In October 1992, the OCC declared the First City-Houston bank insolvent and appointed the FDIC as receiver. On the same day, the Texas Banking Commissioner closed

• Reasons for the Passage of the Single Audit Act of 1984
	• Lack of adequate oversight and accountability for federal assistance provided to state and local governments
	• Reliance on audits of individual grants that focused on specific grant transactions and not on financial controls
	• Haphazard schedule for individual grant audits resulting in large portions of federal funds being unaudited each year
	• Overlapping oversight activities by different agencies

• Objectives and Requirements of the Single Audit Act
	• Promote sound financial management and effective internal control
	• Establish uniform requirements for audits of federal awards
	• Promote efficient and effective use of audit resources
	• Reduce burdens on state and local governments, Indian tribes, and nonprofit organizations
	• Ensure that federal departments and agencies rely upon and use audit work done pursuant to the act
	• Require state and local governments that receive at least $100,000 in federal financial assistance to have a single audit conducted
	• Adopt the single audit concept to help meet the needs of federal agencies for grantee oversight and grantees’ needs for single, uniformly structured audits
	• Focus on internal control and the recipient’s compliance with laws and regulations governing the federal financial assistance received
	• Require grantees to address material noncompliance and internal control weaknesses in a corrective action plan
	• Perform single audits in accordance with GAGAS issued by GAO
	• Refine the Single Audit Act of 1984 and establish uniform requirements for all federal grant recipients through the Single Audit Act Amendments of 1996
	• Increase the audit threshold to $300,000 and require the Director of OMB to designate a Federal Audit Clearinghouse as the single audit repository
	• Criteria for determining which entities are required to have a single audit based on the total amount of federal awards expended by the entity.

• Medicare's contracting process differs from most federal programs
	• Under the Social Security Act, Medicare can deviate from the FAR (Federal Acquisition Regulation)
	• Intermediaries are selected through a nomination process by provider associations
	• Carriers are chosen by the Secretary of Health and Human Services from a small pool of health insurers
	• Medicare could benefit from various contracting reforms
	• Using only health insurers for claims administration may not be ideal due to the increase in information technology and contractor attrition
	• Allowing Medicare to hire separate contractors for specific claims administration activities could improve program management
	• Current regulations prevent CMS from awarding separate contracts for individual claims administration activities
	• CMS has experience with functional contracting under authority granted in 1996 for program safeguards
	• Allowing Medicare to offer financial incentives to contractors for high-quality performance and terminate contractors more efficiently may promote better program management.

• The Department of Defense (DOD) aims to increase investments in modernization without increasing the overall defense budgets, focusing on reducing support operation costs and infrastructure.
	• The Office of the Secretary of Defense (OSD) requested the Defense Science Board (DSB) to identify DOD activities that could be done more efficiently by the private sector and determine the expected savings from outsourcing.
	• The DSB's first report focused on outsourcing and privatization issues, concluding that DOD could save 30-40% of logistics costs by outsourcing support services. The second report had a broader scope, including other methods for reducing infrastructure costs.
	• The DSB estimated that an aggressive DOD outsourcing initiative could generate savings of $7 billion to $12 billion annually by fiscal year 2002, primarily through outsourcing support functions.
	• The DSB suggested that DOD invest about $6 billion but would ultimately save about $30 billion annually by the year 2002, with $6 billion from CONUS logistics infrastructure activities.
	• The DSB's estimate of $14 billion for CONUS logistics costs is considered conservative, as the Navy has reported more than $8.5 billion applied to maintenance programs in fiscal year 1996.
	• DOD has significant opportunities for reducing logistics costs and improving performance by changing its business processes, as found in best practices within the private sector and ongoing work at DOD.
	• Achieving significant cost savings may require up-front investments, the closure of installations, and the elimination of military and civilian jobs, which DOD officials recognize as difficult and painful.
	• Overcoming cultural resistance to outsourcing logistics activities and setting forth a clear framework for a reduced defense infrastructure are key to effectively implementing savings.

• Downsizing of federal agencies in the 1990s led to a reevaluation of how agencies operate and work to reinvent themselves
	• Actions taken to maintain performance during downsizing generally fell into three categories: refocusing missions, reengineering work processes, and building and maintaining employee skills
	• Examples of refocused missions include BOR changing its emphasis from water project construction to water resources management, and NASA's Human Space Flight program shifting its focus to research and development
	• Reengineered work processes included consolidating functions into fewer locations, aligning operations with private sector business practices, and increasing reliance on contractors
	• Components took steps to build and maintain skilled workforces, such as retraining employees for additional responsibilities and consolidating expertise in fewer locations
	• Despite concerns about the sufficiency of current or future workforces, most officials, employee representatives, and employees believed that performance had been maintained during downsizing
	• Limited customer survey data generally supported the view that customers remained satisfied, but some customers of the Office of Housing and BOR did not agree
	• Officials, employee representatives, and employees largely believed that open lines of communication and soliciting employee input into the planning process were key to maintaining performance during downsizing
	• NASA officials also emphasized the importance of treating employees with compassion, avoiding favoritism, and backing up critical skills to prevent a sudden loss of expertise.

• NRP's (National Research Program) main elements include casebuilding, classification, and audits to obtain detailed information about overall compliance, develop formulas to select likely noncompliant returns for audit, and identify compliance problems for the IRS to address.
	• The casebuilding process compiles available data to establish the accuracy of information reported by taxpayers on their returns. Classification determines whether an NRP audit is necessary and which items need to be verified through an audit. NRP audits will address all issues identified by classifiers and will not be focused only on substantial issues or cases for which there is a reasonable likelihood of collecting unpaid taxes.
	• IRS designed NRP to minimize the burden on taxpayers by compiling NRP casebuilding materials that allow IRS to verify certain items on tax returns without requesting the information from the taxpayer, classifying returns according to items that need to be verified through an audit, and limiting most NRP audits to items that cannot be verified without an audit.
	• IRS plans to use NRP data to update return selection formulas, allow IRS to design prefiling programs that will help taxpayers comply with the tax law, and permit IRS to focus its limited resources on the most significant areas of noncompliance.
	• IRS conducted two tests of NRP processes prior to implementing the program, testing the casebuilding and classification processes in an NRP simulation in July 2002, and conducted another classification process test during the initial classification training session in September 2002. IRS used the preliminary results of both of these tests to estimate NRP classification outcomes and to evaluate the effectiveness of NRP training.

- The 2010 Census planning process has improved since the 2000 Census, but there are still areas for improvement.
		+ The Bureau has not yet developed an overall project plan that includes milestones, estimated costs, coordination, and measurable goals.
		+ The Bureau's principal goal to increase coverage and accuracy lacks specific numbers, making it difficult to evaluate costs and benefits, determine resources needed, measure progress, and hold managers accountable.
	- The Bureau is lacking data and information on the performance of key census activities and operations from the 2000 Census.
		+ The Bureau had trouble obtaining quality productivity data following the 2000 Census, and the adjustment was coarse and addressed just one of the two known problems.
		+ The Bureau lacks useful performance information in the extent to which the dozen or so separate activities used to build MAF in 2000 contributed to its overall accuracy relative to one another.
	- The Bureau's three-legged stool strategy assumes that all three legs must work together to achieve its goals.
		+ Lacking information on trade-offs, the Bureau maintains that its only alternative to the reengineering is to repeat the 2000 Census design.
		+ The Bureau needs to balance the growing cost, complexity, and political sensitivity of the census with meticulous planning.

• The Military Health System (MHSS) spends over $15 billion a year on medical readiness, which includes providing medical support during combat and maintaining the health of active-duty military personnel during peacetime.
	• Psychiatrists and clinical psychologists play a crucial role in the MHSS medical readiness mission by providing mental health care that helps military active-duty personnel perform their duties before, during, and after combat or some other military operation.
	• The MHSS created the Prescribing Psychologist Demonstration Project (PDP) to increase the scope of practice of clinical psychologists in the military so they could treat their patients with psychotropic medication when needed.
	• The PDP was established in response to a conference report dated September 28, 1988, which accompanied the fiscal year 1989 DOD Appropriations Act (P.L. 100-463).
	• The Army’s Office of the Surgeon General was tasked with designing and implementing the PDP, and a blue ribbon panel was formed to determine the best method for implementing the PDP.
	• The PDP consisted of 2 years of training, including classroom and clinical training, and PDP participants were trained to take medical histories, incorporate them into treatment plans, and prescribe medication for patients with certain types of mental disorders.
	• After completing their clinical year, participants received a certificate of “Fellowship in Psychopharmacology for Psychologists” and became known as “prescribing psychologists.”
	• The PDP produced additional providers who can prescribe and some facilities have reported positive experiences with them, but determining the PDP’s cost-effectiveness is impossible at this time. The total cost of the PDP will be about $6.1 million through the completion of the proctored year for those currently in the program.
