* The laparoscopic transabdominal preperitoneal (TAPP) mesh repair is a standard treatment for inguinal hernia in adults.
	+ However, it is associated with a higher incidence of early postoperative pain, which can lead to chronic pain.
* The ideal mesh material is still being debated, but mesh fixation with fibrin glue or self-fixating mesh with microhooks has advantages in reducing chronic groin pain.
	+ Guidelines suggest that the use of a 10-mm trocar in the umbilical region or in the oblique abdominal wall can predispose patients to local nerve or vessel injury and port-site hernia.
* Modified TAPP repairs by needlescopic surgery (ntapp) and TAPP repairs in single-incision laparoscopic surgery (stapp) have been proposed with good initial results.
	+ A direct comparison between these two advanced minimally invasive approaches is still missing.
* The study compares the perioperative extent of surgical trauma and its postoperative impact on the abdominal wall after ntapp and stapp repair.
	+ The study recruited 85 patients with a single-sided primary inguinal hernia and compared demographic and surgical data between the two groups.
* The ntapp procedure required significantly less operating time than the stapp procedure (54.8 vs 85.9 minutes, p < .001).
	+ The reduction in operative time was particularly seen in cases of direct hernia.
* The mean measured umbilical skin incision length was significantly smaller in the ntapp group (13.4 mm vs 27.3 mm, p < .001).
	+ Only two patients in the stapp group required an additional 5-mm trocar port in the lateral abdomen.
* Regarding immediate postoperative pain, there was a tendency for longer pain duration in the wound region after the stapp procedure (ntapp, 5.6 vs stapp 9.8 days, p = .072).
	+ Stapp patients also experienced greater wound pain intensity when they began to resume their regular daily activities after hospital discharge.

• Study on correlation between nasopharyngoscopy and cephalometry in diagnosing hyperplasia of pharyngeal tonsils
• 55 children from 3 public schools evaluated, aged 7.0 to 11.11 years
• Inclusion criteria: complaints related to mouth breathing, normal neurological development, no craniofacial malformation or syndromes, no history of pharyngeal surgery
• Exclusion criteria: evident neurological disorders, craniofacial malformation, syndromes, history of pharyngeal surgery
• Both nasopharyngoscopy and cephalometry used to check for the presence or absence of nasopharyngeal obstruction
• Main findings:
	• Spearman's rank correlation coefficient (rho) between nasopharyngoscopy and cephalometry was 0.52, indicating a significant regular and positive association
	• Sensitivity of cephalometry was 35%, negative predictive value was 97%, positive predictive value was 87%, and negative predictive value was 72%
	• Cephalometry tended to underestimate the size of pharyngeal tonsils compared to nasopharyngoscopy
	• A negative cephalometric exam might not provide a proper assessment of the nasopharynx when compared to the nasopharyngoscopic exam
	• Similar results were obtained in other studies comparing cavum radiography and flexible nasopharyngoscopy
	• Children with classical symptoms of respiratory obstruction should undergo flexible nasopharyngoscopy in order to achieve a more accurate diagnosis.

• IBTR can be classified as TR or NPT
• TR: regrowth of malignant cells not removed by surgery or not killed by radiotherapy
• NPT: de novo cases of malignancies arising from mammary epithelial cells of the residual breast tissue
• Differentiating TR from NPT through genetic sequencing or molecular techniques such as DNA fingerprinting, loss of heterozygosity pattern, or allelic imbalances profile

• Study details
		• Prospective study of 502 Korean male hypertensive patients without history of aortic aneurysm (AA)
		• Non-contrast CT of whole aorta, clinical characteristics, and risk factors collected
	• Prevalence and risk factors of AA
		• Prevalence of thoracic AA (TAA) and abdominal AA (AAA) was 36.5% and 6.0%, respectively
		• Determinants for TAA: age, absence of dyslipidemia, larger body surface area, higher diastolic blood pressure, and presence of AAA
	• Association between AA and dyslipidemia
		• TAA was associated with absence of dyslipidemia, while AAA was significantly associated with the presence of dyslipidemia
		• Possible explanations include different etiologies between ascending and descending aorta and well-controlled serum lipids in the studied population
	• Clinical implications and future research
		• TAA was more prevalent in patients with AAA and in high-risk elderly hypertensive patients
		• Most TAA had a diameter < 50 mm, indicating a need for further evaluation of clinical implications
		• Low prevalence of AAA in Asian populations and the impact of smoking on AAA prevalence
		• Need to define the usefulness of routine screening for AAA among Asian non-smokers
		• Primary limitation: CT scans could not accurately evaluate the very proximal portion of the ascending aorta including the aortic root
		• Results cannot be applied to females, other ethnicities, or groups with a low risk of cardiovascular disease
		• Future research should establish distinct screening strategies for TAA and AAA according to risk factors and ethnicity.

* Digital mammography (DM) is the most commonly performed procedure for breast cancer detection
- DM is less likely to be lost or damaged, and has slightly higher sensitivity than screen-film mammography (SFM)
- Despite evidence from DMISST that DM offers some improved benefit in women with dense breast tissue, breast cancers can still be obscured by overlapping tissue
- Tomosynthesis, a 3-D procedure, may help solve this problem by decreasing the problem of confusing overlapping tissue
* DM has been in use for over 30 years and has replaced SFM in most practices in the US
- DM enables viewing and manipulation of DM images on computer workstations
- Radiation dose is a concern with mammography, given that it is a screening examination performed on millions of women potentially every year
- A specific digital system using slot scanning with a photon-counting detector has been found to reduce doses by 40%-60% and has shown the lowest mean glandular dose in clinical screening settings in Europe

* One limitation of both SFM and DM is false positives (recall for additional imaging)
- Women have been recalled for additional imaging from the earliest days of mammogram screening
- Recalls can also lead to false-positive biopsies, which are time-consuming for the radiologist and patient, and stressful and inconvenient for the patient
- Recall rates in the US are about twofold higher than in Europe, with guidelines in the US at overall < 10%, compared to guidelines in Europe of 3%-7% (< 5%)
- If the additional views for evaluation of abnormal screening mammograms could be reduced, this would be advantageous to patients, referring physicians, and radiologists

* Digital breast tomosynthesis (DBT) also uses x-rays like conventional mammography, but creates image slices of a tissue volume
- DBT is a mammography-based technique using breast compression similar to 2-D DM, but obtains multiple low-dose images using a moving x-ray tube head rotating across the breast in an arc
- DBT images can be obtained in any of the usual mammogram views or planes
- Compression of the breast for tomosynthesis is similar to that of conventional mammography, but

• Diphenhydramine classified as antitussive by the FDA

• Aging is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease due to endothelial dysfunction
	• Endothelial dysfunction is characterized by reduced vasodilator substance output and increased endothelium-derived contracting factors
	• Oxidative stress and inflammation are prominent features of the aging process that contribute to endothelial dysfunction
	• Oxidative stress reduces nitric oxide (NO) bioavailability and promotes a chronic inflammatory state
	• Exercise training can prevent and restore age-related impairment of endothelial function by restoring NO availability and alleviating inflammatory processes
	• Exercise increases the release of anti-inflammatory cytokines such as IL-4 and IL-10, and suppresses pro-inflammatory cytokines such as TNF- and IL-6
	• IL-6 has both pro- and anti-inflammatory effects, and exercise-induced increases in IL-6 correlate with muscle mass and exercise intensity, stimulating lipolysis and fat oxidation while reducing glycogen levels during endurance exercise.

- Introduction of non-native species has caused significant environmental and economic damage for centuries
	+ Phylloxera destroyed grapevines in Europe in the 1860s
	+ Chestnut blight eliminated a dominant tree species in North America in the early 20th century
- Research on biological invasions increased significantly in the mid-1980s due to an international project by the Scientific Committee on Problems of the Environment (SCOPE)
	+ Over 100 prominent scientists worldwide were engaged
	+ Several widely read edited volumes were produced
- Research on biological invasions has shown that impacts of introduced species are more varied and widespread than previously thought
	+ Impacts can occur at the ecosystem level, affecting nutrient cycles and other processes
	+ Molecular genetic research has revealed a great number of cases of hybridization and introgression with native species
- Introduction of new species can cause substantial evolution of native species
	+ Hybridization between native and introduced species can even produce new, more invasive species
	+ Molecular genetic features such as microsatellites, mitochondrial DNA, and single-nucleotide polymorphisms have been used to trace sources and routes of invasions
- Invasional meltdown and lag effects are two new lines of research in invasion biology
	+ Invasional meltdown refers to introduced species facilitating one another's establishment or enhancing one another's impact on native species
	+ Lag effects refer to the delay in widespread establishment and impact of an introduced species after initial arrival
- Criticism of invasion biology and management has arisen, with some critics calling for an end to the field
	+ Criticisms fall into five categories, including overblown problems, increased native biodiversity, xenophobia, hopeless battle, and inhumane methods
	+ Criticism 2, which is based on the fact that introduced species can increase native biodiversity, should be tempered by the fact that many complete species extinctions have been caused by introduced species
- The majority of introduced species have not been studied in their introduced ranges, making it difficult to determine their impact
	+ One of the major recent research thrusts of invasion biology is unraveling various ecosystem impacts
	+ Of introduced terrestrial vertebrates and freshwater plants and animals

• Patient's case:
   • 49-year-old woman with multiple sclerosis (MS) presented for follow-up evaluation after an acute flare of MS.
   • Incidentally found a 19 x 13 x 10 mm ovoid mass along the inferior margin of the right cavernous sinus on routine surveillance brain MRI.
   • Mass was biopsy-proven schwannoma of the vidian canal.
   • Patient decided to pursue treatment with radiation therapy (stereotactic radiotherapy) due to the benign histology, background of MS, and young age.

• General information about schwannomas of the vidian canal:
   • Extremely rare type of intracranial tumor with variable presentation.
   • Symptoms can result from compression of surrounding structures or extension into surrounding areas.
   • Dysfunction of the vidian nerve itself may cause nasal dryness, decreased lacrimation, and corneal desiccation.
   • Traditional and curative management is surgical; radiation therapy is an alternative option.
   • Conservative management through observation with serial imaging is also reasonable in certain cases.
   • The choice of treatment modality depends on patient choice, functional status, presenting symptoms, tumor location, tumor volume, and malignant potential.
   • Radiation therapy has become a common alternative to surgical resection of intracranial schwannomas.
   • Options include single-fraction stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS) or conventional daily low-dose fractionation over approximately five weeks.
   • SRS is a well-tolerated procedure, typically completed during a single session of irradiation and far more convenient for the patient.
   • SRS has a high success rate of durable tumor control with often partial reduction in tumor volume.
   • Radiation therapy has been reported in several studies to result in decreased mortality and fewer treatment-related complications for vestibular schwannoma including hearing loss and facial weakness.
   • When a vidian canal tumor is identified, endoscopic biopsy can be used to confirm a histopathologically benign diagnosis before considering treatment options.

• Posterior transpedicular pedicle screw fixation is commonly used for managing unstable spines, often caused by trauma and burst fractures.
• Short-segment fixation has become popular for better correction of kyphotic deformity, greater initial stability, early painless mobilization, and indirect decompression of the spinal canal. However, it is associated with loss of reduction and instrumentation failure in some cases.
• A study was conducted to compare the stiffness of a short-segment pedicle fixation using either monoaxial or polyaxial pedicle screws placed at the level of a burst fracture in a calf experimental model.

• Twelve fresh-frozen calf lumbar specimens (L1-L5) were obtained from a regional slaughterhouse and randomly divided into two groups: monoaxial pedicle screw (mps) group and polyaxial pedicle screw (pps) group.
• An unstable burst fracture was created in the L3 vertebra using the pre-injury and dropped-mass technique. A short-segment posterior pedicle screw construct was used to realign and stabilize the spine.

• Each specimen was tested for flexion, extension, lateral bending, and axial rotation as an intact spine, as a fractured spine, and as a fractured spine fixed by either a 4-screw or 6-screw construct.
• Biomechanical data were evaluated using a general linear model procedure for analysis of variance (ANOVA) and the student Newman-Keuls post hoc test in each group.
• The differences in ROM between the two groups were evaluated with independent t-tests, and the differences in ROM within the same group were evaluated with paired t-tests.

• Use of electrochemical self-assembly (ESA) of nanostructured hybrid thin films of inorganic semiconductors and organic dyes
• Bypasses high-temperature sintering needed for nanoparticulate TiO2 electrodes, allowing for the use of conductive plastic substrates

• Demonstration of ESA with ZnO structures for the construction of photoanodes
• Minor addition of water-soluble dye molecules with substituents for anchoring to ZnO surface impacts crystal growth and crystallographic orientation of the film
• Coprecipitation of dye molecules does not necessarily deteriorate the crystallinity of ZnO

• Formation of vertically aligned interconnected and crystalline nanowires of ZnO with aggregates of Eosin Y (EY) in the space between the nanowires
• Solid EY can be completely removed by soaking the hybrid film in a mild alkaline solution
• Prepared ZnO thin films, consisting of large single-crystalline grains with internal porous structure, have large surface area for adsorption of photosensitizer dye and high crystallinity for efficient transport of electrons
• Achieves high incident photon to current conversion efficiency (IPCE) of around 90%

• Nasopharyngeal bursitis is a condition that originates from the area of communication between the notochord and the foregut.
• It is believed to be a remnant of embryonic communication that normally disappears during fetal development.
• There are two types of nasopharyngeal bursitis: cystic and crust.
• The cystic type is more common and forms when the embryonic remnant becomes obstructed, while the crust type forms when crusts adhere to the orifice without obstruction.
• Symptoms of nasopharyngeal bursitis include space-occupying lesion symptoms (nasal obstruction, eustachian tube obstruction, dysphagia, cranial nerve paralysis) or rhinitis symptoms (choanal discharge, halitosis, pharyngitis, laryngitis, bronchitis, gastritis).
• The incidence of nasopharyngeal bursitis is approximately 4% in adults, but it can appear at any age.
• A clinicoanatomical audit was conducted to identify the incidence of nasopharyngeal bursa disease, its different types, and its clinical presentation over two years in a single rhinology practice.

* Melanoma skin cancer incidence has been increasing, with an estimated 76,250 new cases and 9,180 deaths in the USA in 2012.
	+ Australia has one of the highest skin cancer rates.
	+ Early diagnosis is crucial for prognosis.
* Dermoscopy is a noninvasive diagnostic technique that visualizes morphological features not discernible by the naked eye.
	+ Different techniques, like solar scan, epiluminescence microscopy (ELM), cross-polarization epiluminescence (XLM), and side transillumination (TLM), increase visualized details.
	+ Dermoscopy improves diagnosis compared to the unaided eye, with a 10-30% increase in diagnostic sensitivity.
	+ However, dermoscopy may lower diagnostic accuracy in inexperienced dermatologists.
	+ Sensitivity and specificity in skin lesion diagnosis are 90% and 59% for experts, but drop to 62-63% for general practitioners.
	+ Diagnosis is highly dependent on subjective judgement and scarcely reproducible.
	+ Scoring systems and algorithms have been proposed to improve diagnostic performance for less experienced clinicians.
* Automated analysis of digitized images obtained by ELM techniques has gained interest in the last two decades.
	+ Computational intelligence methods help physicians and dermatologists in faster data processing for better and more reliable diagnoses.
	+ Studies on automated classification of pigmented skin lesion images have been reported since 1987.
	+ Various border detection, feature extraction, selection, and classification algorithms are used in different systems.
	+ More research is needed to identify and reduce uncertainties in automatic decision support systems to improve diagnosis accuracy.
	+ A comprehensive up-to-date review of automatic diagnostic models for skin lesions is not available.
	+ Continuous emergence of new classification algorithms and techniques for dermoscopic image analysis necessitates such a review.

</summary>

• In the US, approximately 20 million adults have gallstones and 1 million new patients are diagnosed with cholelithiasis each year, making it the most costly digestive disease with an estimated annual cost of over $5 billion.
• In 1992, the National Institute of Health convened a conference to discuss the treatment of cholelithiasis and laparoscopic cholecystectomy, concluding that it offered substantial advantages over traditional open cholecystectomy with no increase in morbidity or mortality.
• The reduction in pain and disability with laparoscopic cholecystectomy results in equal or slightly less treatment costs compared to open cholecystectomy, with substantial savings to patients and society due to the shortened period of disability.
• The disability and loss of income following standard open cholecystectomy further increase cost, but these items are generally not measured by traditional appraisal methods. This convalescent period and, consequently, costs have been greatly reduced by laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
• A retrospective review of 70 cholecystectomy patients was conducted to determine the charges for laparoscopy by comparing 35 converted laparoscopic cholecystectomies with 35 open cholecystectomies, matched for age, sex, and similar diagnosis.

- Prevalence of oral mucosal lesions in elderly population
  * 64% of the 5,100 geriatric patients in the study presented with various oral lesions
  * Most common lesions: nicotinic stomatitis (43%) and denture stomatitis (34%)
- Risk factors and causes
  * Use of tobacco and related products, faulty dentures, and systemic diseases such as diabetes mellitus can increase the risk of oral lesions
  * Bacterial, fungal, viral, and parasitic infections, physical and thermal alterations, immune system changes, tumors, trauma, and other factors can also contribute to changes in the oral mucosa
- Gender and site predilection
  * Slight male preponderance in the present study
  * Hard palate (23.1%) was the most commonly affected site, while soft palate (3.6%) was the least involved
- Comparison with other studies
  * Prevalence of mucosal changes or lesions was higher in the present study (64%) compared to findings by Mujica et al. (57%) and Espinoza et al. (53%)
  * Denture stomatitis was the second common lesion (34%), while it was the most common lesion in the study by Mujica et al. (18%)
- Implications and recommendations
  * Increased number of aged individuals requires adequate planning in social-, economic-, and health-related areas
  * Community programs should be enhanced to educate the elderly population and the younger generation about oral-mucosal lesions and the importance of screenings

• Chondroblastoma is a rare bone tumor that accounts for less than 1% of all primary bone tumors and affects the epiphyseal regions of the tubular bones.
• In the head and neck region, chondroblastoma characteristically occurs in the temporal bone or the temporomandibular joint and can result in various symptoms such as occlusal abnormalities, trismus, clicking of the TMJ, hearing impairments, dizziness, and otorrhea.
• Malignant changes in chondroblastoma are rare but have been observed after irradiation, making radiation therapy not a suitable treatment option.
• Chondroblastoma in the temporal bone has unusual histological features that make diagnosis difficult, and incomplete resection carries a high risk of recurrence.
• A case of chondroblastoma in the temporal bone is presented, where the initial diagnosis was delayed due to relying on imaging analysis without careful MRI/CT scanning analysis or histopathologic examination.
• The patient was a 41-year-old male with a history of chronic hearing loss on the right side, initially diagnosed with TMJ disorder.
• After several attempts at antibiotic therapy and treatment for eustachian tube blockage, the patient underwent endoscopic surgery, but his symptoms were unresponsive.
• Re-examination of the CT scan and pathologic examination showed the presence of a giant cell tumor in the temporal bone.
• The patient underwent a modified surgical procedure, including radical mastoidectomy, subtotal resection of the temporal bone, and skull base dissection with resection of TMJ using a zygomatic-extended middle fossa approach.
</summary>

• Study findings suggest that objectively measured physical activity is not greatly predictive of risk at an individual level for developing nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and visceral adiposity.
• Despite this, regular structured physical activity has been shown to reduce visceral adiposity and liver fat, reflecting current physical activity guidelines that advocate structured exercise for health benefits.

<summary>

• Study findings suggest that objectively measured physical activity is not greatly predictive of risk at an individual level for developing nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and visceral adiposity.
• Despite this, regular structured physical activity has been shown to reduce visceral adiposity and liver fat, reflecting current physical activity guidelines that advocate structured exercise for health benefits.

• A cross-sectional analysis found no relationship between current habitual activity levels and vat or liver fat, but it does not account for lifetime levels of habitual activity.
• Objective assessment of activity via accelerometry is considered more accurate than self-report methods, but participants may still have altered their usual behavior during monitoring.

• Epidemiological data at the population level suggest that physical inactivity is associated with the development of NAFLD and visceral adiposity, and reducing sedentary behavior should be generally advocated in all populations.
• However, the study found that the inclusion of objectively measured levels of moderate activity and sedentary behavior did not improve the potency of traditional risk factors for predicting liver fat concentration or level of visceral adiposity.

• Regular structured physical activity has been shown to reduce vat and ihl, reflecting current physical activity guidelines that advocate structured exercise for health benefits.
• The volume of activity required for benefit is much greater with general habitual activity, and increasing incidental activity is important for increasing total daily energy expenditure.

• High levels of cardiorespiratory fitness are a characteristic of the phenomenon termed metabolically healthy obesity, and low cardiorespiratory fitness is an independent predictor of all-cause and cardiovascular disease mortality.
• The emphasis for behavior change in this population should arguably be on adopting and adhering to structured exercise programs, cognizant of individual barriers to participation in exercise and exercise preferences.

- Study details:
	+ Retrospective, observational, consecutive case series conducted in a tertiary eye care hospital in north India.
	+ Included patients with history of fireworks-related injuries who attended the emergency eye care services and outpatient services during the 5 days of the Diwali festival for 5 consecutive years from 2011 to 2015.
	+ Recorded relevant data including age, sex, laterality, type of firework, whether user or bystander, baseline visual acuity, details of injuries, diagnosis, management, and final best-corrected visual acuity at the last follow-up.
	+ Patients with lid tears, corneal tears, scleral tears, and intraocular foreign body were admitted and given immediate medical and surgical attention, while those with nonpenetrating injuries were treated on an outpatient basis.
- Results:
	+ A total of 53 eyes of 45 patients were seen during the 5 consecutive days of the Diwali festival from 2011 to 2015.
	+ The right eye was affected in 30 eyes, while the left eye was affected in 23.
	+ Five eyes (9.43%) had an open-globe injury, while 48 (90.56%) had closed-globe injury.
	+ Six patients had undergone primary treatment elsewhere and were referred to the hospital for further management.
	+ One patient with a corneal epithelial defect required amniotic membrane transplant and glue with a bandage contact lens.
	+ Eighteen (33.96%) eyes underwent surgical management at the institute, 34 (64.15%) eyes were managed conservatively, and only 1 (1.88%) eye was advised primary enucleation.
	+ Five eyes eventually developed phthisis bulbi, of which three eyes underwent secondary enucleation with ball implant and ocular prosthesis.
	+ Visual acuity could not be assessed in 12 injured eyes, of which three patients (6 eyes) were of the pediatric age group.
	+ Three patients (6 eyes) were lost to follow-up.

- **Subclinical hypothyroidism (SCH)**
	+ Definition: isolated elevation of TSH levels with normal FT4 levels
	+ Common causes: chronic autoimmune thyroiditis, inadequate thyroid hormone supplementation, poor adherence to treatment regimen, drug interactions, inadequate monitoring of treatment
	+ Prevalence: 4% to 20% in the adult population, with women, elderly people, and iodine-sufficient populations being affected more often
	+ TSH reference range: should be standardized and appropriate quality control procedures established by each laboratory
	+ TSH cutoff values and clinical significance: controversial
	+ Treatment: typically considered for pregnant patients, those who are infertile, exhibit associated symptoms, or have a high risk of progression to overt hypothyroidism
- **Associations of SCH with various clinical conditions**
	+ Weight and BMI: higher levels of TSH are associated with increased BMI and enhanced weight gain
	+ Blood pressure (BP): higher levels of TSH are associated with worsening BP
	+ Lipid levels: elevated levels of serum total cholesterol, LDL-C, apolipoprotein B, lipoprotein(a), and possibly triglycerides are reversed in individuals with overt hypothyroidism following levothyroxine therapy
	+ Cardiovascular disease (CVD): SCH is associated with increased CVD risk, including hypercoagulability, insulin resistance, oxidative stress, and endothelial dysfunction
	+ Metabolic syndrome (METS): SCH is associated with increased risks of all-cause mortality and CVD, and the odds of having METS are positively associated with TSH levels within the reference range
	+ Thyroid hormones and the heart and vasculature: SCH can lead to impaired systolic and diastolic cardiac function, and older people with SCH and a high CV risk appear to be at an increased risk of incident heart failure
	+ Mortality: TSH levels within the normal range are inversely associated with all-cause mortality, and adult Taiwanese subjects with SCH were shown to have an increased risk for all-cause mortality and CVD death over a 10-year

- The DREAM trial was a large, international, multicenter, double-blind, randomized controlled trial designed to determine whether ramipril and/or rosiglitazone could prevent or delay the development of type 2 diabetes in people with IFG or IGT.
  - IFG and IGT are metabolic states that indicate very high risk for eventual progression to diabetes.
  - A total of 5,269 participants with these disorders were recruited and randomized to either ramipril and/or rosiglitazone using a two-by-two factorial design and followed for a median of 3 years after randomization.
- The primary outcome variable in the present study was change in β-cell function over the course of follow-up.
  - β-cell function was assessed using two measures: the insulinogenic index (IGI) and proinsulin (PI) concentration.
  - IGI and PI concentration were divided by HOMA-IR and c-peptide concentration, respectively, to account for the compensatory response of insulin secretion in relation to background insulin resistance.
- Participants receiving rosiglitazone had a significant increase in IGI/IR and a significant decrease in PI/C, while there were no significant changes in participants receiving ramipril.
  - The impact of rosiglitazone on IGI/IR and PI/C was similar within subgroups of IIGT and IFG+IGT, although effects were more modest in those with IIFG.
  - Rosiglitazone significantly increased IGI and reduced PI concentrations over time after adjustment for age and insulin resistance.
- After accounting for baseline β-cell function as measured by either IGI or PI in models that adjusted for insulin resistance and other covariates, rosiglitazone significantly reduced the risk of developing diabetes.
  - Adjusting for the change in β-cell function as measured by IGI attenuated the preventive effect of rosiglitazone on incident diabetes, while such attenuation was not noted when the change in β-cell function was measured using PI.
- The study suggests a significant improvement in β-cell function with TZD treatment in pre-diabetic subjects.

- **Microbial communities vs monocultures**
	+ Degrade different toxins
	+ Produce different natural products
	+ Capacity to grow in certain environments
- **Metabolic interactions in microbial communities**
	+ Combinatorial interactions supported by complex communities
	+ Strains may exhibit naturally complementary metabolism or be genetically engineered to interact
	+ Interacting partners share metabolites such as hydrogen, acetate, amino acids, fixed nitrogen, or glucose
- **Modeling metabolic interactions**
	+ A general model of metabolic interaction would account for the variety of metabolites that can be exchanged and the genotypic diversity of the strains that exchange them
	+ Optimization-based techniques of flux balance analysis have been successful in describing metabolic systems
	+ These approaches can be extended to higher-order systems of multiple strains in co-culture.

<summary>
	* Biological scaffold materials derived from dermis, pericardium, and small intestine submucosa of human, bovine, and porcine origin have been used in soft tissue repair applications such as hernia repair, breast reconstruction, staple-line reinforcement, and orthopedic applications.
		+ These scaffold materials are particularly useful in clean-contaminated or contaminated settings due to their rapid revascularization and clearance of bacteria.
		+ Permanent, synthetic polymer mesh materials are not typically utilized in these settings due to the risk of infection.
	* Biological scaffolds are also utilized as an alternative to fascial closure when there is excessive tension on the wound, when tissue loss makes closure especially difficult, or in damage-control/abdominal compartment settings in which the abdomen must be left open until the patient is stabilized.
		+ In these settings, scaffolds are utilized to protect the abdominal contents, typically until granulation of the wound occurs and a split-thickness skin graft can be applied.
	* Although biological scaffolds present many attractive advantages, these materials are also extremely expensive, exhibit substantial scaffold variability, and provoke patient-specific immunological responses.
	* Early designs of absorbable polymer scaffolds included materials such as Dexon (Covidien, Mansfield, MA) and Vicryl (Ethicon, Inc., Somerville, NJ).
		+ Dexon is comprised of polyglycolic acid (PGA), and it degrades in vivo via hydrolysis.
		+ Full resorption of the PGA is expected to be complete in approximately 60-90 days (2-3 months).

• Treatment with ru (aldosterone antagonist) was generally better in preventing or reversing ischemia-induced cardiac dysfunction in normal hearts compared to treatment with an ACEi (captopril) or ARB (losartan) alone.

• The relative improvement in cardiac function or effectiveness of RAAS blockers was greater in diabetes than in control hearts, except for pmax for ru given after ischemia.

• Ru alone was highly effective at preventing and treating i/r-induced cardiac dysfunction in nondiabetic hearts, whereas in diabetes, it was only effective at preventing i/r-induced cardiac injury before ischemia.

• The effectiveness of drugs generally appeared to be cardiac parameter specific. For example, although ru was ineffective at improving pmax, it was the most effective at improving dp/dt when administered to diabetic hearts after ischemia.

• The study showed that ru importantly improves diastolic function (as measured by dp/dt) in diabetes especially when given after ischemia and thus early-stage ru treatment may represent a novel strategy for treating diabetes-induced diastolic dysfunction.

• Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the leading cause of mortality in many economically developed nations, accounting for about 30% of all deaths.
• Ongoing research aims to investigate and prevent the early development of cardiovascular risk factors such as atherosclerosis, hypertension, dyslipidemia, chronic inflammation, and insulin resistance.
• N-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (n-3 PUFAs) have beneficial effects on CVD, including lipid lowering, anti-inflammatory, antithrombotic, antiatherosclerotic, and antiarrhythmogenic effects.
• Atherosclerosis is a systemic disease characterized by low-grade arterial inflammatory lesions, and endothelial cells synthesize and release adequate amounts of nitric oxide and prostaglandins to maintain a downstream balance between pro- and anti-inflammatory molecules.
• In the presence of atherosclerosis, this balance disrupts, leading to an increase in proinflammatory cytokines such as interleukins 1, 2, and 6 and tumor necrosis factor, which can induce oxidative stress and further progression of the disease.
• PUFAs and their eicosanoid derivatives may play a significant role in modulating the inflammatory response.
• The human body can produce almost all fatty acids except linoleic acid (LA, c18:2 n-6, precursor to the n-6 series of fatty acids) and -linoleic acid (ALA, c18:3n-3, precursor to the n-3 series of fatty acids).
• The biochemical pathways converting ALA to EPA and EPA to DHA are limited, and tissue and circulating EPA and DHA levels are primarily related to their dietary intake.
• Fish is the major food source of long-chain n-3 PUFAs, including EPA, DHA, and docosapentaenoic acid (DPA), while ALA is a plant n-3 fatty acid mainly found in seeds, nuts, and their oils.

	• Rudolf Virchow, the "father of modern pathology," proposed that cancer arises from chronic irritation or inflammation.
	• Pelayo Correa, a Colombian pathologist, published a model for gastric cancer development in 1975, hypothesizing a stepwise process beginning with chronic atrophic gastritis and progressing to intestinal metaplasia and cancer over 30-50 years.
	• Robin Warren and Barry Marshall discovered H. pylori and its role in gastritis and peptic ulcer disease, winning the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 2005.
	• Initial investigations into a possible association of H. pylori with gastric cancer provided weak evidence, but later cohort studies with nested case-controls found a significant correlation.
	• The World Health Organization's International Agency for Research on Cancer declared H. pylori a definite (Group 1) carcinogen in 1994 based on epidemiologic studies, despite a lack of supporting evidence from animal models or basic science research.

		- H. pylori eradication can reduce the risk of developing gastric cancer.
	• A pilot study of mass population screening and eradication in Taiwan has shown promising results, with gastric cancer incidence decreasing by approximately 25%.

• Advancements in understanding the VEGF-A signaling pathway have led to the development of various agents targeting different components of the pathway, including VEGF-A itself, VEGF receptors, PTKs, and signaling intermediates.
		+ Avastin, a humanized mAb to VEGF-A, has been widely used in combination with cytotoxic chemotherapy for various human cancers.
		+ However, there is a need for other drugs that could be combined with avastin to deliver improved clinical outcomes.
	• Other VEGF family members, such as VEGF-B, VEGF-C, VEGF-D, and PIGF, have been identified, enhancing the diversity of signaling induced by the VEGF family of ligands.
		+ VEGF-C and VEGF-D are closely related and have been associated with poor patient outcome in some tumor types.
		+ Animal models have demonstrated that VEGF-D can promote tumor angiogenesis and lymphangiogenesis, solid tumor growth, dilation of collecting lymphatic vessels, and lymphatic and distant organ metastasis.
	• Inhibiting signaling by VEGF family members could potentially have pro-tumor effects.
		+ Recent studies have demonstrated that anti-angiogenic treatments could cause increased tumor metastasis through mechanisms such as the induction of hypoxia.
		+ Other signaling pathways, such as those driven by members of the PDGF, IGF, and FGF growth factor families, exert control on tumor angiogenesis and may be important in promoting tumor growth.
	• Other alternative molecular targets, such as c-met, may also be able to affect multiple tumor properties such as metastasis, angiogenesis, tumor growth, and cellular motility upon hypoxia.
		+ Recent studies have indicated the role of known inflammatory pathways in enhancing the spread of cancer.
		+ The use of existing anti-inflammatory drugs in cancer could provide a cost-effective and population-based preventative approach to cancer in Asian countries.

• Causes of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH)
• 	• Autosomal recessive disorder
• 	• Deficiency in adrenal enzyme resulting in altered cortisol and aldosterone secretion
• 	• 95% of patients have 21-hydroxylase deficiency (21-OHD) caused by inactivating mutations in the CYP21A2 gene
• Clinical forms of CAH associated with 21-OHD
• 	• Classical CAH: severe form with salt-wasting (SW) and simple virilizing (SV) subtypes
• 	• Non-classical (NC) CAH: less severe form with postnatal or adult onset hyperandrogenism
• Treatment of CAH
• 	• Glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid replacement to prevent adrenal crises and suppress abnormal androgen secretion
• 	• Conventional glucocorticoid replacement cannot mimic natural circadian rhythms of cortisol release
• 	• Over- and under-suppression of glucocorticoids can lead to iatrogenic Cushing's syndrome, obesity, decreasing growth velocity, virilization, menstrual disorders, infertility, growth suppression, and development of adrenal tumors
• MRI abnormalities in CAH patients
• 	• Hormonal imbalances during early development and exposure to excess exogenous glucocorticoids are probable explanations for these MRI findings
• 	• White matter changes and temporal lobe structures dysgenesis are common in CAH patients due to 21-OHD
• 	• Chronic hyperandrogenism due to non-compliance with treatment may be the main mechanism involved in the genesis of brain MRI abnormalities in CAH patients.

• Gene annotation and function prediction:
   • Two main approaches: empirical observations and predicted evolutionary relationships
   • Empirical observations are currently restricted to characterized genes
   • Predicted evolutionary relationships rely on homology and conserved domains

• Homology and conserved domains:
   • Homologous genes have similar tertiary structures and frequently similar functions
   • Homology is based on evolution, not function
   • Subtle sequence similarities can indicate homology

• Pitfalls of homology-based annotation:
   • Homologs may not share similar molecular mechanisms
   • Divergent homologs or non-homologs can have overlapping functions

• Domain resources for annotation:
   • Pfam, SMART, Prosite, Celera, and TIGR predict domains using multiple sequence alignments
   • InterPro combines domain and motif sets for annotation

• Proteome annotation by domain content:
   • Protein function is a synthesis of component parts
   • Approximate descriptions of molecular function for uncharacterized genes
   • Domain architecture prediction does not allow prediction of cellular function or phenotypic effect

• Future of gene annotation and function prediction:
   • High-throughput studies of non-vertebrate model organisms
   • Detailed predictions of molecular and cellular roles from orthologs
   • Integration of functional aspects, such as cellular role and protein-binding partners, with domain predictions

• Importance of common vocabulary and efficient navigation of genomes:
   • Gene Ontology project (GO) creates a defined hierarchy of terms for function
   • Cross-community approach to dealing with functional vocabulary
   • Orthology prediction and domain family subfamilies with distinct functions will guide efficient genome navigation.

- Stem cells have three functional characteristics: self-renewal, proliferation, and multipotency.
  * Self-renewal is the ability to make identical copies of themselves.
  * Proliferation is the ability to multiply and increase in number.
  * Multipotency is the ability to give rise to various cell types.
- Identification of lung stem cells has been challenging due to the low turnover rate of lung epithelia.
  * However, populations of stem cells have been identified in the lung through their role in the response to injury.
  * The functional tenets of stem cell behavior have been observed in these cells, including self-renewal, proliferation, and multipotency.
- The earliest stages of lung malignancies may be related to a deregulation of the stem cell-based repair mechanism.
- The airway progresses from proximal to distal in a stereotyped fashion, with different types of epithelium in each region.
  * Cells capable of stem-like behavior in response to airway injury are present throughout the airway.
  * In proximal airways, tracheal basal cells have been identified as pluripotent and able to give rise to cells of multiple phenotypes in response to injury.
  * In middle airways, mature clara cells have been shown to proliferate into phenotypically diverse progeny in response to injury.
  * In distal airways, the cell surface marker phenotype of representative lung stem cells remains under debate.
- The hierarchical or cancer stem cell hypothesis is an important theory in understanding lung tumorigenesis.
  * Relatively rare, multipotent cells gain unlimited proliferative potential and drive tumor growth.
  * The multipotent nature of these cells leads to heterogeneity within the tumor.
  * A stem-like cell with the ability to rapidly proliferate into phenotypically diverse progeny could act as the cancer stem cell.
- Stem cells express high levels of anti-apoptotic and drug-resistant proteins, which may explain why chemotherapy is ineffective against localized recurrence and metastatic disease.
- Recent studies have identified cells within lung cancer specimens that exhibit stem-like properties.

   • Group B patients had a higher fistula rate and failed 8 fr calibration compared to Group A (p = 0.004 and p = 0.01, respectively)
   • Patients with flat urethral plates had a higher fistula rate and failed 8 fr calibration compared to those with cleft or deeply grooved plates (not statistically significant)
• Conclusion:
   • Urethral plate width and character play a role in the success of tip repair
   • Flat and narrow urethral plates may require augmentation with buccal mucosal graft to improve results.

- Development of a prototype to measure bracket debonding force in vivo
	+ A prototype was developed to measure the bracket debonding force in vivo using a strain gauge connected directly to the extremity of the pliers where the bracket debonding occurs.
	+ The prototype was compared in vitro with the tensile bond strength test in a universal testing machine.
- Design of the prototype
	+ The prototype consists of three basic parts: a modified plier, a measurement and control circuit, and a PC with specific software.
	+ The modified plier has an intermediate part positioned between the active arm of the pliers and the claw, where a strain gauge is directly connected.
- Testing of the prototype
	+ The accuracy and precision of the prototype were measured using weights ranging from 1 to 6 kg.
	+ The prototype was used to bond maxillary central incisor brackets to the enamel and measure the bracket debonding force.
- Results of the prototype
	+ The prototype showed no significant difference in mean bond strength compared to the tensile test in a universal testing machine.
	+ Debonding with the prototype was shown to be a safe method for preserving the enamel surface.

- Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome (LGS) is a catastrophic epilepsy of childhood, characterized by specific types of seizures, EEG patterns, and cognitive impairment.
	+ Seizure types: tonic, atonic, atypical absence, myoclonic, generalized tonic-clonic, or partial.
	+ EEG patterns: slow spike wave discharges (less than 3 Hz) and paroxysms of low voltage fast activity at about 10 Hz during sleep.
	+ Cognitive impairment: moderate to severe mental retardation and behavioral disorders including aggression and autistic features.
	+ Etiologies: cortical maldevelopment, perinatal hypoxia-ischemia, CNS infection, or neurometabolic disorders.
- Rufinamide, a novel anticonvulsant drug, has shown promising potential for treatment of LGS and other seizure types.
	+ Mechanism of action: decreased firing of high frequency sodium-dependent action potentials and prolongation of sodium channel inactivation.
	+ Efficacy: rufinamide significantly decreased total seizures and tonic-atonic seizures in a double-blind randomized placebo-controlled trial involving 138 patients with LGS.
	+ Safety profile: rufinamide has an excellent safety profile in animals and lacks obvious cognitive side effects and behavioral toxicity at clinically relevant doses. In a multicenter study of 189 adolescent and adult patients with partial seizures, 12 weeks of treatment with rufinamide failed to cause deficits in several measures of cognitive function.
	+ Pharmacokinetics: rufinamide is well absorbed, has low protein binding, and is eliminated primarily via metabolism. Drug-drug interactions are likely to be minimal, but careful elucidation is necessary in conditions like LGS where polypharmacy is usual.

• The scientific production of the Faculdade de Medicina da Universidade de São Paulo (FMUSP) was analyzed, focusing on full professors who were on staff between 2001 and 2006.
	• During this period, the 66 full professors published a total of 1,960 articles, representing 0.04% of worldwide scientific publications, 2.4% of national publications, 4.3% of the FMUSP's all-time total publications, and 12.33% of its total publications during the same period.
	• Of these articles, 68.7% were published in international journals and 31.3% in Brazilian journals.
	• The obligatory use of English in some Brazilian journals has led to better visibility and accessibility of research results.
	• However, few Brazilian journals have Impact Factors (IFs) available, and only 17.39% of the total number of Brazilian journals that have assigned IFs (2006 JCR) were represented in this study.
	• The study also found that the average publication rate of the full professors was five articles per year per professor.
	• The analysis of IFs should consider specific research areas and the kind of publication, as some areas have a greater number of researchers compared to others.
	• The articles counted in this study were published in journals with IFs varying from 0.063 to 51.296.
	• The bibliographic record data in this study can be useful in analyzing the scientific production of a group of professors from the FMUSP and for establishing a basis for comparison with other institutions in Brazil.

• Rubella infection during early stages of pregnancy has a 90% potential of passing through the placenta and affecting the fetus, leading to congenital rubella syndrome (CRS).
• Vaccination of susceptible individuals, especially women in reproductive age, can prevent the disease and its complications. The primary purpose of rubella vaccination is to prevent CRS, which affects an estimated 110,000 infants each year in developing countries.
• In Iran, the rubella and mumps vaccines were added to the national vaccination plan in 2003, resulting in 98% vaccination of the 5 to 25 age group. This has significantly decreased the appearance of measles and rubella.
• A study in Kermanshah, Iran, compared the susceptibility and resistance of Kermanshahi girls at marriage before and after mass rubella vaccination. The study found a significant increase in immunity after vaccination.
• Further studies on rubella seroepidemiology are recommended to monitor the immunity status of vulnerable society members, such as pregnant women, and to ensure timely vaccination if necessary.

• The rubella vaccination was established in Australia in 1971 and in Denmark in 1987, leading to a significant decrease in CRS.
• A seroepidemiological study in Chahar Mahal-va-Bakhtiari province, Iran, in 1997, using the hemoagglutination inhibition (HI) method, indicated 90.5% immunity against rubella.
• A study in Tabriz, Iran, in 1999, using the ELISA method, found 85.83% immunity to rubella.
• A study in Ghaem Shahr, Iran, in 1997, found 90.75% immunity to rubella in high school girls.
• A study in Kermanshahi girls at marriage in 1999 found that 20% of them were susceptible to rubella, leading to the prescription of screening and vaccination before marriage.

• Whole mount in situ hybridization (WISH) is a technique used to visualize gene expression patterns in biological systems.
• Gene-specific RNA probes are used to detect the expression of specific genes during development, providing valuable information about the role of these genes and the positioning and movement of specific cell types.
• The use of fluorescent methods for detecting transcripts has several advantages over chromogenic methods, including higher quality three-dimensional imaging, multiplexing different RNA species, and covisualization of RNA with proteins.
• However, the use of fluorescent methods for WISH is not yet widespread due to the high endogenous background fluorescence of many embryos and the limited brightness and photostability of organic fluorophores.
• Quantum dots (QDs), a new type of inorganic fluorophore, have ideal optical properties for use in biology and have been used successfully for in situ hybridization in clinical biopsies for the detection of multiple mRNAs.

• QDs have several advantages over organic fluorophores for use in WISH, including a strong fluorescent signal emission, wide excitation spectra, narrow and tunable emission spectra, large separation between the excitation and emission, and resistance to photobleaching.
• These unique optical properties make QDs an ideal candidate for detecting multiple mRNAs in WISH protocols and their high fluorescence intensity raises the possibility of using them for RNA detection in whole embryos.
• Previous efforts to use QDs for RNA detection in whole embryos have met with aggregation issues and were time-consuming due to the need for RNA to be covalently linked to hydroxylated QDs.
• New methods for creating hydrophilic QDs and the availability of hydrophilic QD conjugates have addressed these issues, but studies have pointed out difficulties in using QDs for fish experiments, including steric hindrance, degradation of QD conjugates, and adherence to tubes and tips.

• The greatest limitation of QDs for use in WISH is penetration, as commercially available QDs are quite large and therefore fail to penetrate the many cell layers of an embryo

- **Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) survival factors**
  * Gender, race, age at diagnosis, marital status, and time period of diagnosis have a significant impact on PDAC survival.
  * Tumor size, nodal status, and distant metastases also significantly influence PDAC survival.
  * Surgical resection of the tumor has the most dramatic influence on survival, but only 20% of patients are suitable for this procedure.
- **Cox proportional hazards regression models for PDAC survival estimation**
  * Two nomograms have been developed using Cox proportional hazards regression models to estimate survival for patients who have undergone pancreatectomy and to predict the risk of perioperative mortality in PDAC patients scheduled for pancreatectomy.
  * A new interactive, online clinical calculator has been developed based on two Cox regression models to estimate survival probability for patients diagnosed with PDAC, based on individual clinicopathological profiles.
  * A web-based, real-time prognostic tool has been developed using SEER data and Cox proportional hazards regression models to estimate survival and conditional survival probabilities for patients with PDAC.
- **Limitations of Cox models for PDAC survival prediction**
  * Cox models may be inaccurate for up to 30% of patients due to the use of variables provided by SEER and the absence of information on co-morbidities and chemotherapy data.
  * Estimation of the prognostic index may be accurate for the majority of the observed PDAC population but inaccurate for relatively small, yet very important patient subpopulations.
  * The lpdac and epdac models developed in this work have advantages over existing models and tools, including applicability for the vast majority of PDAC patients, real-time prediction of conditional and unconditional survival probabilities, and the use of additional covariates.

• **Internet addiction and its prevalence**
	• Explosive growth in internet use in India and worldwide in the last decade
	• Prevalence among college students in Mumbai: 24.8% possible addicts, 0.7% addicts
• **Components and types of internet addiction**
	• Identified by Griffiths, Davis, and Young
	• Types: cyber-sexual addiction, cyber-relationship addiction, net compulsions, information overload, computer addiction
• **Effects of internet addiction on mental and physical health**
	• Poor mental, physical, and mental health scores in addicts
	• High anxiety, depression, and anxiety-depression scores in addicts

The source text discusses the explosive growth in internet use in India and worldwide in the last decade. In the city of Mumbai, a cross-sectional survey of college students found that 24.8% were possible addicts and 0.7% were addicts according to Young's original criteria. Internet addiction has been identified as a subset of behavior addiction by Griffiths, and as a dependency on psychoactive substances by Davis. Young has adapted the DSM-IV criteria to relate to internet use and developed the Internet Addiction Test (IAT) to measure the severity of self-reported compulsive use of the internet. Internet addiction can have negative effects on mental and physical health, with addicts having poor mental, physical, and mental health scores and high anxiety, depression, and anxiety-depression scores.

• Factors affecting aspirin recommendations and usage
  • The Framingham Risk Score (FRS) was not predictive of receiving a physician recommendation for aspirin for primary prevention.
  • Education level, insurance status, and having a regular source of care were predictive of receiving a recommendation for aspirin for cvd prevention among primary prevention patients.

• Disparities in aspirin recommendations and usage
  • Nonhispanic whites were more likely to receive a recommendation for aspirin than were asians/others among primary prevention patients.
  • Lack of health insurance and a usual source of care may contribute to racial/ethnic disparities in primary prevention.

• Impact of risk level on aspirin recommendations and usage
  • Only 40.9% of patients at high risk reported having been told by their physician to take aspirin.
  • The benefit of using aspirin in low-risk patients who do not have clinical CVD is negated by the risk of harms from gastrointestinal bleeding.

• Limitations of the study
  • The study only examines adults age 40 and over.
  • The study does not know how many respondents were recommended to take aspirin for heart attack or stroke prevention versus for cancer prevention.

• Study on the impact of delivery mode on women's postpartum physical and mental health related QOL
• Prospective study of pregnant women admitted for prenatal care in health centers in Kashan city, Iran
• Excluded women with pre-existing diseases, history of infertility, divorce, instrumental delivery, low birth weight, child or fetal death, child abnormality, not breastfeeding, and medical problems in child and mother
• Used Iranian version of Short Form-36 Health Survey (SF-36) to measure QOL, categorized into physical and mental health
• Compared women's socio-demographic characteristics and physical and mental health scores between women with vaginal delivery (VD) and cesarean section (CS)
• Physical health score in VD women was higher than CS group at 2 months follow-up (60.52 ± 13.28 and 57.37 ± 12.20, p = 0.034)
• At 4 months postpartum, VD group had higher score in total physical health (61.37 ± 13.05 and 58.36 ± 14.09, p = 0.05) and total mental health (64.99 ± 12.44 and 61.83 ± 13.58, p = 0.036)
• VD group showed more improvements on total mental HRQOL from time 1 to time 2 assessment (mean score differences: 4.70 ± 16.29 and 0.3 ± 13.81, p = 0.01)
• Recommendations for future studies to include both general and specific questionnaires in assessing postpartum QOL among women with VD, elective CS, and emergency CS, and to recognize social and cultural factors related to physical and mental HRQOL after delivery.

• Maslow's hierarchy of needs, proposed in 1943 and 1954, suggests that human needs can be categorized into five levels, arranged in a pyramid with the most fundamental levels at the bottom.
• Physiological needs, the most basic level, include food, sex, and other physical requirements for survival.
• Safety needs, the next level, involve personal and financial security, as well as health and well-being.
• According to Maslow, if physiological needs are satisfied, safety needs become the dominant organizing force for behavior.
• Safety needs can also block physiological needs, as shown in Miller's avoidance and approach experiments.
• The amygdala, a limbic structure in the brain, is the neural basis for fear and stress-elicited fear and anxiety.
• The fast-acting thalamus-amygdala circuit is an evolutionary adaptation that allows for rapid recognition of dangers to aid in survival.
• The ne/lc system is important for directing behaviors in response to dangerous environments, with the well-known function of inducing fight or flight behaviors.

• Maslow's hierarchy of needs is a well-known theory that proposes human needs can be categorized into five levels, arranged in a pyramid with the most fundamental levels at the bottom.
• Physiological needs, the most basic level, include food, sex, and other physical requirements for survival.
	+ These needs are the foundation of the pyramid and must be satisfied before higher level needs can be addressed.
• Safety needs, the next level, involve personal and financial security, as well as health and well-being.
	+ These needs are related to personal safety and are more fundamental than physiological needs.
	+ For example, a deer cannot eat if it is being chased by wolves.
• According to Maslow, if physiological needs are satisfied, safety needs become the dominant organizing force for behavior.
	+ Maslow proposed that if the physiological needs are relatively satisfied, there then emerges a new set of needs, which may be categorized roughly as the safety needs.
	+ The organism may be wholly dominated by them, which may serve as the almost exclusive organizers of behavior.
• Safety needs can also block physiological needs.

- Epoxyeicosatrienoic acids (EETs) are involved in various physiological functions such as blood pressure regulation, nociception, adipogenesis, anti-inflammatory activity, organ regeneration, insulin potentiation, podocyte integrity, and cellular responses to bacterial infection.
	+ The most prominent regioisomer, 14,15-EET, and other members of this autacoid family arise via metabolism of arachidonic acid by cytochromes P450.
	+ The ratio of EET isomers and their stereocomposition are isoform-dependent and species- and tissue-specific.
- Numerous chemical and metabolic factors complicate investigations into the roles of 14,15-EET and restrain its potential therapeutic utility.
	+ The susceptibility of 14,15-EET to aerial or auto-oxidation necessitates handling and storage under strict conditions.
	+ In biological milieu, hydration of the epoxide by soluble epoxide hydrolase (sEH) is a major determinant in maintaining the steady-state levels of 14,15-EET, whose half-life has been estimated at no more than seconds to minutes.
- Inhibition of sEH can elevate EET levels both in vitro and in vivo, offering an indirect means for pharmacologic intervention in EET-mediated processes.
	+ However, this strategy might prove less efficacious than an agonist replacement therapy whenever endogenous EET biosynthesis is compromised.
	+ To address some of the stability limitations of natural EETs, laboratories have prepared several iterations of EET surrogates with improved stability.

- The Patient-Centered Medical Home (PCMH) model is an extension of the Chronic Care Model (CCM) and aims to provide quality, coordinated, and cost-effective care to patients.
  - The CCM was developed to address the increasing rate of patients with chronic conditions in the US using team-based care.
  - The PCMH model strives to increase access to services, practice efficiency, provider and patient satisfaction, and reduce healthcare costs while improving patient care quality.
- The transition to PCMH can be challenging, but over 1,500 sites and 7,700 clinicians across the US have successfully completed the National Committee for Quality Assurance (NCQA) recognition process.
  - Encouraged by the expansion of PCMH across the US, medical practitioners and healthcare administrators met in Alexandria, Virginia, to discuss their experiences with the transition.
  - Carillion Clinic and the Air Force contributed the vast majority of the examples and experiences discussed in the paper.
- To become recognized as a PCMH by the NCQA, a practice must provide documentation of the practice's guidelines for implementation.
  - Practices must create their own written policies that adhere to PCMH principles and fit the specific practice structure.
  - Practices must account for their patient panels, location, and financial resources when creating policies.
- The PCMH model introduces team-based care to primary care practices, requiring staff to address patient treatment decisions collectively.
  - Previous studies show the use of previsit huddles has resulted in improved decision-making and care for patients.
  - Patients provided with team-based care had increases in their satisfaction levels from 5 to 10 points in five out of six satisfaction care scales.
- Implementing the PCMH model requires significant changes in office culture.
  - The healthcare organization must understand how changing positions within the practice brings new experiences to all of their current members and how these experiences can potentially affect their capability of delivering care.
  - Every healthcare model must take into account patients' response to the new healthcare structure.
- PCMH connects patients with resources in the healthcare system and the community.

	* Varicocele is a contributing factor in male infertility, accounting for approximately 40% of cases
		+ Characterized by enlargement and elongation of the pampiniform plexus, venous convolution, and sinus formation
		+ Etiopathogenesis is unclear, but hypothesized to be due to retrograde flow of renal metabolites and adrenal hormones to the testis
		+ Can lead to atrophic changes within convoluted tubules, compromising testicular oxygen concentration and testicular growth in children and adolescents
		+ Diagnosis is based on inspection and palpation, confirmed by accessory ultrasound and doppler examination
		+ Treatment is surgical repair for palpable varicocele with testicular hypotrophy on the affected side
		+ Retrospective study of 68 adolescents who underwent laparoscopic repair from 1996-2011 showed significant increase in testicular volume and improvement in semen parameters
		+ Hormonal regulation of the reproductive system in adolescent boys and men depends on sertoli and leydig cells stimulation by pituitary lh and fsh
		+ Postoperative follow-up and hormonal tests are necessary for objective evaluation of the efficacy of surgical varicocele repair
	</summary>

- Different types of stem cells studied
- Advantages and limitations of each type
- Strategies to improve stem cell therapy
- Role of paracrine factors in stem cell therapy
- Future directions and challenges

	- Embryonic stem cells (ESCs) can differentiate into cardiovascular lineages but have ethical concerns and risk of teratoma formation.
	- Induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) can be generated from adult somatic cells and differentiate into functional cardiovascular lineages, but risk of tumorigenesis needs to be eliminated.
	- Mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) can differentiate into osteoblasts, chondrocytes, and adipocytes, and can be induced to differentiate into cardiomyocytes. They can be rapidly expanded in culture and are less immunogenic, but their propensity to differentiate into non-cardiac tissues limits their use.
	- Skeletal myoblasts can be harvested from muscle biopsies, expanded in culture, and autologously reimplanted, but they do not differentiate into true cardiomyocytes in vivo and their contractions are dyssynchronous due to failure of electromechanical coupling with the surrounding myocardium.
	- Bone marrow-derived mononuclear cells, including hematopoietic and endothelial progenitor cells, can differentiate into cardiomyocytes, endothelial cells, and smooth muscle cells in culture and after transplant, and can supply a broad range of paracrine factors with proangiogenic, positive remodeling, and antiapoptotic properties.
	- Improving stem cell homing to diseased myocardium has the potential to enhance both the safety and efficacy of cardiovascular cell therapy by increasing cardiac retention and reducing potential side effects.

• Polyhalite is a mineral commonly found in sedimentary evaporite successions and in rare cases in volcanic successions.
	• It was first described in Austria and has since been found in many salt deposits worldwide.
	• Polyhalite is associated with various other minerals in evaporites, including halite, anhydrite, glauberite, carnallite, kieserite, langbeinite, vanthoffite, chlorides, and sulphides.
	• The crystal structure of polyhalite was first determined in samples from Altaussee, Austria, and has been confirmed by subsequent studies.
	• Polyhalite can be synthesized in the laboratory under specific conditions, and its dehydration temperature has been found to start at 255°C and reach a maximum of 343°C.
	• Substitution of divalent cations by other elements significantly affects the dehydration reactions of polyhalite.
	• Polyhalite forms early diagenetically by brine-back reactions of K-Mg-SO4 brine with earlier formed gypsum, anhydrite, or glauberite.
	• It is stable between room temperature and 255-343°C, making it useful for absolute age dating in deciphering the geological history of a region.
	• In the Haselgebirge evaporite succession in the Northern Calcareous Alps, polyhalite is a minor but widespread and important constituent, occurring mainly intergrown with anhydrite or as vein fillings.

- Nonsurgical endodontic retreatment is the primary choice to eliminate or reduce microbial content in failed teeth
		+ However, well-compacted root fillings can make it difficult to access the apical foramen and impair disinfection and reshaping
	- Different instrumentation techniques are used for retreatment, including hand files, engine-driven rotary retreatment files (RFS), ultrasonic tips/files, and heat-carrying instruments
		+ Rotary files can successfully remove the bulk of gutta-percha-based fillings, but complete removal is not always achieved
	- Extruded irritants from retreatment can cause postoperative inflammation, flare-ups, and impaired healing
	- A study was conducted to evaluate the extrusion of debris apically after the use of Protaper Universal RFS and different finishing files for removing residual root canal fillings
	- The finishing files used were Protaper Next (PTN), Waveone (WO), and Self-Adjusting File (SAF)
	- The null hypothesis was that the three different supplementary files would exhibit no significant differences in the amount of debris extruded
	- The teeth were cleaned and shaped using Protaper Universal rotary files, and obturation was done by warm lateral compaction
	- The teeth were then kept for 30 days at 37°C and 100% humidity to allow complete setting of the sealer
	- Following this, the teeth were randomly divided into four experimental groups for retreatment
	- The one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) and post hoc test were used to determine the significant group with the alpha-type error set at 0.05

• Study on the anesthetic success of AMSA nerve block using conventional syringe
	• 30 patients, 16 men and 14 women with an average age of 22 years old
	• Lidocaine 2% with epinephrine 1:100,000 used for anesthesia
	• Anesthetic success monitored with electric pulp tester
	• Results:
		• Anesthetic induction times ranged from 6 to 12 minutes
		• Duration of pulpal anesthesia ranged between 23 - 40 min
		• All patients obtained palatal soft tissue anesthesia
		• No patient obtained pulpal anesthesia from the second premolar to the central incisor and facial anesthesia
		• 26.7% of patients had no anesthetic success in any of the experimental teeth
		• No severe pain recorded during the administration of the local anesthetic in the palate
		• Low success rates of conventional syringe system could be due to the superiority of the computer-controlled system to inject the anesthetic solution with a controlled and continuous flow
		• The anesthetic blockade of the five experimental teeth was not obtained in any of our patients
		• The duration of pulpal anesthesia was gradually declining during the 60 minutes
		• The anesthetic solution is deposited on the palatine process of the maxilla for its diffusion, searching the terminal branches of the alveolar nerves
		• It is more of an infiltrative technique than a nerve block
		• The reduction of multiple injections reduces the total amount of delivered vasoconstrictor and may be useful for cardiovascular-compromised patients that required maxillary anesthesia
		• For maxillary mucogingival procedures, the AMSA nerve block with palatal delivery of anesthetic with vasoconstrictor provides excellent hemostasis and reduces the need for multiple re-injections to obtain hemostatic control during periodontal procedures or graft harvest

- Malaria in India and Jammu and Kashmir:
	+ Malaria is a serious public health problem in India and Southeast Asia, with India contributing 76% of the 2.5 million cases in the region.
	+ In Jammu and Kashmir, malaria cases are concentrated in the Jammu division, with an annual parasite incidence (API) of 0.11, while the Kashmir division has an API of less than 0.1.
- Study on Knowledge, Attitudes, and Practices (KAP) regarding malaria in Jammu and Kashmir:
	+ A community-based descriptive cross-sectional study was conducted in RS Pura health block of Jammu district in Jammu and Kashmir state in North India.
	+ The study found that knowledge about malaria was high among the study participants, with 97% correctly associating malaria with mosquito bite and 90.5% knowing that malaria could be prevented. However, only 56% knew that malaria could be fatal if not treated.

• Recent advances in molecular biology and microscopy technologies have improved our understanding of genome folding
		• The genome is folded in a hierarchical manner into chromosome territories, genomic compartments, and topologically associating domains (TADs)
		• TADs are stable units of chromosomes that exhibit higher frequency of physical contacts between genes and their regulatory regions
		• TAD boundaries are enriched for certain histone marks, CTCF, cohesin, and DNase I hypersensitivity, and are associated with the timing of replication domains
		• The strength of TAD boundaries is regulated by the binding of insulators and enzymes that modify or remodel chromatin
		• The major ATPase subunit of the SWI/SNF chromatin remodeling complex, Brg1, is required for proper nucleosome occupancy and positioning at target regions and for establishing long-range chromatin interactions
		• Brg1 contributes to TAD boundary strength and its loss affects nucleosome occupancy and higher order chromatin organization

	• Brg1 knockdown in human mammary epithelial MCF-10a cells results in the differential expression of genes related to extracellular matrix and lipid synthesis and many long non-coding RNAs
		• Brg1 primarily binds at genic regions (60%) and intergenic Brg1 peaks include super-enhancers
		• The majority of TAD boundaries are largely overlapping between control and Brg1 knockdown cells, but more than 10% of the TAD boundaries are unique to either the control or the Brg1 knockdown cells
		• The strength of TAD boundaries is significantly reduced in Brg1 knockdown cells, resulting in a higher frequency of inter-TAD genomic interactions
	• Brg1 plays a role at TAD boundaries by regulating nucleosome occupancy and possibly CTCF localization
		• The orderly positioning and occupancy of nucleosomes at TAD boundaries may be achieved by enriched CTCF binding
		• The binding of CTCF and topoisomerases may be perturbed by Brg1 loss or knockdown, resulting in altered nucleosome occupancy and

<summary>
	* The study uses statistical modeling, specifically Poisson and Negative Binomial regressions with zero inflated, to analyze the number of failed courses and semesters in students of Iran University of Medical Sciences.
		+ The data was collected from the university education file and the deputy head of the university in students affairs.
	* The descriptive statistics and zero inflated Poisson and Negative Binomial regressions were used to analyze the final data set.
		+ The number of students with no failed courses was 71.3%, and 28.7% had one or more failed courses.
	* The Poisson regression for the number of failed courses showed that a unit increase in university average resulted in a decrease in the logarithm of the number of failed courses.
		+ The number of failed semesters, change of educational level, gender, and marital status also had an effect on the number of failed courses.
	* The regression of failed semesters showed that the university average had a negative relationship with the numbers of failed semesters.
		+ The quota system and the number of failed courses also had an effect on the number of failed semesters.
	* The results of the regression models showed that the university average and quota system had an inverse relationship with the response variable.
		+ An increase in the university average and a change from other quota system to free quota system caused a decrease in failed semesters.
	* The increase in the number of failed courses resulted in an increase in the logarithm odd of inflated zero.
		+ This indicates that with an increase in the number of failed courses, the chance of having failed semesters increases.
	* The regression models with the response variable of the number of failed courses showed that the university average and the bachelor and master educational levels had a negative relationship.
		+ The change from other educational levels to bachelor and master levels caused a decrease in the number of failed courses.
	* The study was supported by Iran University of Medical Sciences under the grant number of 370.
	</summary>
