• The control of appetite is complex and involves both physiological and environmental factors.
	• Early theories focused on signals from glucose metabolism, amino acids/proteins, or adipose tissue, forming the glucostatic, aminostatic, and lipostatic hypotheses.
	• More recent models emphasize inputs from adipose tissue and the gastrointestinal tract, as well as sensory features of food.
	• Major signals include leptin from adipose tissue and hormones such as ghrelin, PYY, GLP-1, CCK, amylin, and insulin from specialized cells in the GI tract.
	• A new formulation explains how aspects of body composition and energy expenditure (EE) regulate hunger and appetite.
	• This formulation is based on 15 years of psychobiological research with overweight and obese human subjects.
	• The major task for any model of human appetite regulation is to account for the ongoing and recurring drive to eat and intermittent suppression of eating via episodic satiety signalling and tonic inhibition.

	• The interplay between energy expenditure (EE) and energy intake (EI) has led to an alternative approach to appetite control.
	• Any increase in EE is met with an equivalent increase in EI, suggesting that differences in food intake originate in differences in energy expenditure.
	• Edholm's experimental studies revealed no correlation between EE and EI in a single day, but there was a good correlation over two weeks.
	• Resting metabolic rate (RMR) is the largest component of total daily EE and is quite uniform across the day and between days.
	• RMR could provide a tonic signal of energy demand that could act as a driver of daily EI.
	• Physical activity EE, being of greater intensity and sporadic, would exert a mechanistically different type of control over appetite.

	• Exercise can raise resting values of EE several-fold, depending on the volume, mode, and intensity.
	• Exercise has numerous physiological effects, including an overall increase in heart rate, changes in blood flow distribution, sympathetic nervous system activity, gut hormone activity, and nutrient absorption.

  * The goal of the project is to estimate how frequently native perennial warm-season grasses may be established in southern Arizona using 31 years of historical rainfall event data
  * The project simulated soil moisture for a 31-year period using a land surface model with detailed long-term precipitation event data, data on movement of moisture through the soil, and data on evaporation from the Santa Rita Experimental Range
  * The specific practices selected for analysis included seeding on 15 May onto bare soil in southern Arizona, USA, with generic native warm-season grasses assumed to be in the top 0.1 cm of the soil when the monsoon rains began
  * The soil type used in the simulations was a loamy sand, which is common in the region and the primary soil type on a nearby mineland reclamation site
  * Germination and establishment were evaluated over the first 21 days, so competition among seedlings was assumed not to have an impact on plant growth or soil moisture in this period
  * Rainfall data came from gages 5 and 6 from the Santa Rita Experimental Range, which were roughly 45 km south of Tucson, AZ, USA, and recorded the date, time, amount, and duration of each rainfall event
  * Seven years of eddy flux data were also available, including temperature/relative humidity, photosynthetically active radiation, ground heat flux, soil temperature, precipitation, volumetric soil water content at various depths, wind velocity vector, sonic temperature and concentrations of water vapor and carbon dioxide measurements

<summary>
	* **Major Depression (MD) is a significant cause of disability and a major contributor to the global burden of disease.**
		+ By 2020, it is projected to be the second leading cause of disability.
		+ Up to 40% of patients with MD do not show satisfactory improvement after treatment with available antidepressant medications and psychotherapies.
	* **Treatment-Resistant Depression (TRD) is a challenge in mental health care.**
		+ It is defined as a poor response to two adequate trials of two different classes of antidepressants.
		+ Staging methods have been proposed to help researchers and clinicians understand TRD patients and plan interventions.

- **Patient blood management (PBM)** is becoming more recognized due to the risks associated with allogeneic red blood cell (RBC) transfusions, such as increased morbidity and mortality, infections, pathogen transmission, high costs, and blood shortages.
  * PBM is especially important in cardiac surgery, where postoperative severe bleeding is common and can lead to increased morbidity and mortality.
  * Elderly patients and those with long cardiopulmonary bypass times are at a higher risk of postoperative bleeding.
- **RBC transfusion guidelines** recommend that transfusions should not be based on a single hemoglobin (Hb) transfusion trigger, but instead on the patient's risk of developing complications of inadequate oxygenation.
  * Transfusions are generally indicated at Hb levels lower than 6.0 g/dl (3.7 mmol/l) and rarely indicated in patients with Hb higher than 10.0 g/dl (6.1 mmol/l).
  * In many types of major surgery, these recommendations have been followed and the use of transfusions has been reduced. However, in cardiac and vascular surgery, the use of blood and blood products is still common.
- **Antiplatelet agents** are commonly used in patients with coronary artery disease undergoing coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery.
  * Long-term aspirin therapy is the standard of care in patients with coronary artery disease.
  * Concomitant treatment with oral ADP receptor antagonists is recommended for patients with recent acute coronary syndrome (ACS) or percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).
  * Studies have shown both reduced mortality and no difference in bleeding or bleeding complications in patients treated with antiplatelet drugs.
  * However, other studies have reported higher transfusion requirements and increased bleeding and transfusion without an effect on mortality.
  * The use of antiplatelet agents at the time of CABG carries both benefits and risks, and cardiac surgeons must consider the timing of surgery in patients exposed to these drugs.

* Microglia, which were once considered to play no role in the immune system of the central nervous system (CNS), are now known to be crucial for innate immunity within the CNS.
		+ They are derived from erythromyeloid progenitors in the yolk sac that enter the brain during different developmental stages.
		+ Yolk sac erythromyeloid progenitors express the chemokine receptor cx3cr1, and microglial maturation is accompanied by a reduction in cd31 expression and concomitant upregulation of the macrophage marker, f4/80, and macrophage colony stimulating factor receptor (mcsf-r).
	* The CNS immune system is more constitutively active than previously envisioned, with the presence of a conduit that enables communication between the brain parenchyma and cervical lymph nodes via the glymphatic system.
		+ This system facilitates immune surveillance of brain interstitial fluid (ISF) and, along with brain microglia, helps to clear interstitial solutes through the exchange of ISF and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) along the perivascular space.
	* CSD (cortical spreading depression) is a slowly propagating wave of rapid, near-complete depolarization of neurons and astrocytes followed by a period of electrical suppression of a distinct population of cortical neurons.
		+ It is accompanied by secondary changes of cerebral blood flow (CBF) and can be elicited by chemical stimulation, pinprick stimulation, and electrical stimulation of the intact cerebral cortex.
		+ CSD has been recorded in patients with ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke, brain trauma, and migraine, and can initiate inflammatory activation of microglia.
	* Microglia express voltage-sensitive ion channels and are thought to sense electrical activity pertaining to CSD.
		+ CSD initially elevates extracellular pH, which subsequently leads to a gradual decrease in tissue pH.
		+ A recent study revealed that microglia exhibit increased nmda-dependent inward rectifying potassium conductance after CSD

- Transposable elements (TEs) in genomes
		+ TEs were once considered junk DNA, but they have been shown to serve as a genomic reservoir for new regulatory and coding sequences.
		+ They can be molecularly domesticated to form new cellular protein-coding genes, which can have properties of interest for host cellular pathways.
		+ TE-derived genes have been shown to fulfill important functions in plants, fungi, and animals, including vertebrates.
	- Gin genes in vertebrates
		+ Gin genes are derived from the gag gene of ty3/gypsy elements, a super family of LTR retrotransposons.
		+ They have been molecularly domesticated to form multigenic families in fish and amphibians, and are involved in various cellular processes such as placenta development and cell proliferation.
		+ Gin genes are particularly expressed in brain and gonads, and their expression pattern during embryogenesis suggests roles in gastrulation and other developmental processes.
	- Molecular domestication of TEs
		+ Molecular domestication of TEs is an important driver of genetic innovation during evolution.
		+ Many TE-derived genes have been identified in vertebrates and other organisms, and are involved in various cellular processes such as immunoglobulin formation, centromere formation, and DNA repair.
		+ The availability of additional genome sequences will likely lead to the identification of many more TE-derived genes specific to various vertebrate sublineages, contributing to diversification within vertebrates.

• Progressive diseases affecting millions worldwide
	• Common characteristic: misfolding and/or incorrect elimination of distinct polypeptides
	• Ability to amplify and propagate from cell to cell
	• Misfolded protein aggregates create a self-sustaining vicious circle leading to disease
	• Molecular chaperones play a central role in preventing protein misfolding and aggregation
	• Cellular stress triggers heat shock response, leading to partial correction of misfolding
	• Ubiquitin proteasome system and autophagy clear misfolded proteins, but can fail, leading to protein aggregation and disease

	• Misfolded protein aggregation causes loss of function and gain of pathologic function
	• Consequences include permeabilization of plasma membrane, perturbation of membrane protein dynamics, formation of novel pathogenic signaling platforms, trapping of molecular chaperones, and amplification
	• Protein aggregates made of fibrillar material are hallmarks of neurodegenerative diseases
	• Ageing increases the probability of misfolding and aggregation events
	• Recent evidence suggests that other protein aggregates spread in a prion-like manner
	• Misfolded protein aggregates propagation and amplification is a widespread phenomenon in neurodegenerative diseases

	• Distinctive patterns of pathological changes throughout the brain for major neurodegenerative diseases
	• Protein aggregates associated to pathology initiate in circumscribed areas and progress in a topographically predictable manner
	• Observations led to the hypothesis of neurotropic pathogens spreading through defined pathways
	• First evidence for the transmission of misfolded protein aggregates not involving prion protein in man came from the observation that Lewy bodies in PD brains contaminate grafted fetal mesencephalic progenitor neurons
	• Injection of brain extracts containing protein aggregates induces lesions characteristic of the disease in model animals
	• Fibrillar assemblies induced lesions in mice and non-human primates, and lewy bodies appeared in rodents neural grafts implanted in the brains of mice expressing human -syn

	• Aggregation of proteins associated with neurodegenerative diseases can be reproduced in test tubes

• The text is a summary of a meta-analysis study that aimed to determine the association of 2AR (beta-2 adrenergic receptor) polymorphism with ischemic stroke.

• The study used case-control design and included studies published in English with full text, and stroke confirmed by MRI or CT.

• The search keywords used were 'bar', 'bar gene variant' or 2ar, 'beta-adrenergic receptor' or 'beta adrenergic receptor polymorphism', and 'cerebral infarction' or 'cerebrovascular accident' or 'ischemic stroke' or 'brain infarction'.

• Two studies were excluded due to cohort study design, two studies were excluded for studying another gene polymorphism, and one study was excluded for being a pharmacogenetic study.

• Two studies reported genotypic data and were included for genotypic association meta-analysis, and three studies were included for allelic association meta-analysis.

• The meta-analysis results did not show a significant association between arg16gly polymorphism of 2AR and ischemic stroke, but a significant association was observed between gln27glu polymorphism of 2AR and ischemic stroke.

• The study suggests that gln27glu polymorphism of 2AR is an independent risk factor for cardiovascular diseases and cerebrovascular diseases.

• The study has some limitations, including the absence of haplotype analysis, gene-environment and gene-gene interaction studies, selection bias due to hospital-based controls, and deviation from HWE equilibrium in control subjects in one study.

	* **Cell separation techniques** are essential in clinical and basic research, such as in HIV diagnostic tests and stem cell biology.
		+ **Size- and density-based approaches** offer potential for separation of cell subpopulations for which specific markers are not known or can't be used.
		+ **Affinity-based approaches** (fluorescence-, magnetic-, adhesion-, and electrophoretic-based) can provide fast and continuous separation with high specificity.
	* **Microfluidic cell separation devices** have several advantages over conventional techniques, including small sample volumes, portability, low cost, improved sterility, and potential for integration with analytical techniques.
		+ Many of these technologies are derived from the semiconductor industry or synthetic chemistry.
		+ Cell separation techniques can be broadly classified into two categories: size and density, and affinity (chemical, electrical, or magnetic).
	* **Size-based separation processes** are being employed in micro- and nanoscale devices, which are compact, simple, and usually do not require additional energy sources or equipment.
		+ These devices force a fluid containing a heterogeneous particle population through a series of channels or obstacles of varied size, ensuring laminar flow.
		+ The main advantage of the size-based approach is that it does not require the presence of cell-specific markers or proteins to achieve separation.
	* **Adhesion-based separation systems** are akin to chromatography columns, where a mixture is passed through a column packed with beads or other materials capable of binding to the undesired constituents of the feed.
		+ An important advantage of this technique is that it can be used to separate cell populations that have the same size and/or density, such as subpopulations of human lymphocytes.
		+ Microfluidic adhesion-based systems provide high surface areas per unit volume but their small overall volume keeps residence times short.
	* **Microscale magnetic separation** is of particular interest since it can easily be miniaturized and utilized in applications where small sample volume is required.
		+ The major challenge in the design of microscale magnetic separation systems is achieving efficient separation in a continuous (flow through) system.
		+ Macroscale systems remain more attractive in

- Comparison of morphological signs for diagnosing cirrhosis
- The caudate to right lobe ratio (c/rl) and the right posterior hepatic notch (rpn) have similar performance in diagnosing cirrhosis
- The expanded gallbladder fossa (egf) has low sensitivity but high specificity and represents an important additional finding of cirrhosis
- Study limitations
- The study did not evaluate the diagnosis performance of combined c/rl, rpn, and egf
- The study did not correlate the morphological signs with the underlying cause of cirrhosis
- Further studies are needed to determine if these signs might help to differentiate the cirrhosis induced by different causes
- The c/rl, the rpn, and the egf can be calculated and visualized on various imaging techniques, not just MRI.

- Impact of new technologies and innovations on healthcare industry
  * New technologies and innovations can address current challenges in the healthcare industry
  * Can help circumvent the "iron triangle" of access, cost, and quality of care
  * Exponential power of technology can enable disruptive step changes in performance while simultaneously slashing costs
- Decline in funding for research-based institutions
  * NIH lost 22% of its capacity to fund research from FY 2003 to 2015 due to budget cuts, sequestration, and inflationary losses
  * Fewer grants and discoveries, talented scientists and investigators leaving research and/or the US
  * Increasing the efficiency and effectiveness of investments in fundamental research and development is crucial
- Challenges in healthcare innovation
  * Long and challenging journey between unmet need or discovery and a viable commercial product or service
  * "Valley of death" between academic research and commercialization is a key obstacle
  * Non-economic investments and lack of attention to likelihood of commercially motivated investment can hinder success
- Importance of commercial readiness and attractiveness
  * Technologies emerging from labs must be commercially ready and attractive to investors
  * Universities and academic medical centers must do more to prepare and support investigators interested in translating research into practice
  * New skills and resources are needed to focus on creating and developing technologies with a better chance of surviving the commercialization journey
- Approaches to improving translational research
  * Adding a business development function to TTOs can be effective
  * Creating programs to assist academic investigators advance technologies toward commercialization is also effective
  * Providing educational opportunities and hands-on skills development can help investigators understand and address commercialization challenges
- Healthcare Commercialization Programs (HCPs)
  * Balance cost-effective advancement of a project into commercialization with building the skills of team members
  * Two recent examples: modified version of the I-Corps program and the Coulter Foundation C3i program
  * NHLBI established three NIH Centers for Accelerated Innovations (NCAIs) to help advance projects into patient care
- Fundamentals of the I-Corps program
  * Get team members out of the lab to talk with stakeholders, customers in particular

   • The study found that not all patients admit to smoking, and not all follow smoking cessation recommendations
   • The study also found that cotinine detection in urine is a convenient and easy way to verify patients' smoking history

<summary>
	* Prevalence and severity of anal incontinence (AI) are measured by patient self-reporting.
		+ No objective assessment methods exist.
	* Obstetric anal sphincter injury (OASIS) is a main cause of AI in nonpregnant women.
		+ Multiple vaginal deliveries increase the risk of AI regardless of anal sphincter injury.
	* Age, obesity, and medical conditions such as diabetic neuropathy and gastrointestinal disorders also increase the risk of AI.
	* Prevalence of AI among women differs largely in previous studies and between different study populations.
		+ Postpartum studies show a high prevalence of AI in women having suffered from OASIS.
		+ Women attending gynecological outpatient clinics have higher prevalence of AI compared with the general female population.
		+ Women with pelvic floor disorders have higher prevalence of AI than women without pelvic floor disorders.
		+ Community-based studies show differences in prevalence of AI between age groups, with increasing prevalence by increasing age.
		+ The most frequent AI is found among nursing home residents, among the oldest women with frequent additional complaints and comorbidity.
	* Few previous studies have assessed the prevalence of AI in a female population of fertile age, and few studies have included nulliparous women.
	* The aim of this study was to assess the prevalence and risk factors for AI in an unselected female population across parity groups in the second trimester of pregnancy.

• The text discusses the prevalence and risk factors of human papillomavirus (HPV) infection in women.
	• HPV is a DNA virus that can cause cervical cancer and other genital cancers.
	• The infection is common in sexually active adolescents and young adults, with a high prevalence in sub-Saharan Africa.
	• High-risk HPV genital infections in young females are usually transient but can lead to precancerous lesions of the cervix if persistent.
	• Risk factors for HPV infection include heterosexuality, promiscuity, smoking, high parity, early sexual debut, other sexually transmitted diseases, prolonged use of contraceptives, dietary factors, and genetic disorders.
	• The study found that HPV infection was significantly associated with educational status, with women with secondary education having the highest prevalence.

	• HPV infection was not significantly associated with age, tribal origin, marital status, or use of contraceptives.
	• Women with children had a higher prevalence of antibodies to HPV than those without children.
	• Women who had their sexual debut at an early age had a higher prevalence of HPV antibodies.
	• Women with abnormal vaginal discharge had a lower frequency of HPV antibodies than those with normal discharge.
	• Women with a family history of cervical cancer or a history or signs of WHIM syndrome had a higher prevalence of HPV antibodies.
	• The study recommends improving knowledge at the population level about HPV and its vaccines, introducing a subsidized HPV vaccine in Nigeria's national immunization schedule, and implementing cervical cancer screening programs in Nigeria.

• Evidence-based medicine (EBM) is a new paradigm that aims to provide effective, efficient healthcare with minimal complications and errors
• EBM helps fill the knowledge gap between research and routine clinical practice by integrating available best evidence with clinical experience and patient preferences
• The main challenge is transferring and translating knowledge to help physicians make the best clinical decisions in the minimum time
• Despite the benefits of EBM, several factors affect its use, necessitating the development of an integrated system to manage dispersed data and ensure evidence use in clinical decision making
• A national evidence-based healthcare system can ensure the best evidence is generated, stored, used, shared, and monitored for effective and safe services
• Clinical effectiveness is achieved by realizing the best practice, which requires referencing the best local evidence in different parts of healthcare
• An evidence-based health care system (EBHCS) provides local knowledge for evidence-based clinical decision making and guarantees its application among care providers
• A comparative study analyzed the structure and process of EBM in England, USA, Canada, Australia, and Scotland, and the current status in Iran regarding service delivery and medical education
• Strategies and methods were recommended to make EBM implementation more feasible in Iran, focusing on structure, processes, knowledge products, motivation, support, regulation, and performance monitoring
• The study identified barriers to EBM in Iran, including insufficient knowledge of physicians on EBM and lack of motivation for change in the practice system

- Study on optic neuritis related to MS
- Aim: determine onset of optic neuritis as first MS clinical presentation, analyze role and significance of morphometric changes in optic nerve and visual field, determine efficiency of pulse corticosteroid therapy
- Clinical, retrospective study conducted at Eye Clinic and Neurological Clinic, Sarajevo University Clinical Centre (SUCC)
- Sample: 89 patients with verified MS diagnosis, 10 with optic neuritis as first clinical sign
- Age structure: optic neuritis most frequent in patients aged 18-30 years
- Gender structure: optic neuritis more frequent in female patients (70%)
- Ophthalmological parameters: visual acuity (VA) by Snellen charts, visual field (VF) by Octopus 100, thickness of peripapillary rim nerve fibres by Stratus Zeiss Optic Coherent Tomography (OCT)
- Results: significant improvement in VA after pulse corticosteroid therapy, thinning of nerve fibres in whole circumference after three months, centrocecal scotoma in 50% of cases
- All patients with verified MS diagnosis treated with pulse corticosteroid therapy
- Conclusion: optic neuritis is a common first clinical manifestation of MS, pulse corticosteroid therapy effective in improving VA, thinning of nerve fibres a common occurrence in MS patients with optic neuritis.

* Causes of osteoporosis in patients with MS
		+ MS is a chronic progressive disease affecting the myelin sheath covering of nerve fibers in the brain and spinal cord, leading to functional impairments such as visual impairment, abnormal walking mechanics, poor balance, muscle weakness, fatigue, and progressive immobilization.
		+ Impaired mobility or lack of weight-bearing physical activity reduces mechanical stress on bone, causing a marked imbalance in bone remodeling with a disruption of osteocytes network.
		+ Management of MS requires long-term disease-modifying therapy, such as glucocorticoids (GCS), with a further negative effect on bone remodeling and bone strength.
	* Prevalence of osteoporosis and fractures in patients with MS
		+ The analysis of a registry of 9029 patients with MS in the USA found that 27.2% responders reported low bone mass, and more than 15% of responders reported a history of fracture.
		+ Most studies in patients with MS evaluated BMD in comparison with the control group of healthy subjects and showed significantly lower BMD in patients with MS than in controls.
		+ Several studies have shown that vertebral BMD is affected to a lesser degree than femoral BMD.
	* Pathogenic mechanisms of osteoporosis in patients with MS
		+ The underlying pathogenic mechanisms of the osteoporosis in patients with MS are probably based on the progressive immobilization, long-term GCS treatment, vitamin D deficiency, skeletal muscle atrophy, and possibly on the presence of various cytokines involved in the pathogenesis of MS.
		+ Chronic use of other drugs, such as antidepressants, may contribute to the development of osteoporosis and fractures.
		+ The functional impairments also lead to an increased risk of falling that, combined with bone loss and impaired quality of bone mass, can increase the frequency of bone fracture in individuals with MS.
	* Effects of GCS treatment on bone health in patients with MS
		+ GCS are frequently used to control MS relapses.
		+ Oral GCS treatment in patients with MS may increase the risk

• Frequency and symptoms of vivax malaria before and after treatment
   • Before treatment: fever, chills, sweating, weakness, headache, arthralgia, lower back pain, retroocular pain, and gastrointestinal symptoms such as bitter taste, decreased appetite, nausea, vomiting, and pain in hypogastric or mesogastric region.
   • After treatment: significant reduction in fever, arthralgia, back pain, and retroocular pain, but significant increase in nausea, diarrhea, pale stools, abdominal pain, bitter taste in the mouth, weakness, and hypochondrial pain.

• Side effects of antimalarial drugs and their impact on treatment adherence
   • Chloroquine and primaquine can lead to the onset of symptoms and intensify or reduce some of the symptoms of malaria.
   • The occurrence of symptoms specifically related to the intake of antimalarials and the overlap of symptoms of malaria with the side effects of primaquine and chloroquine may decrease adherence to treatment.

• Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, and Huw Morris, director of the skills, higher education and lifelong learning group in Welsh Government, attended a meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee to discuss the post-legislative scrutiny of the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015.
		• The discussion covered topics such as the potential repeal or amendment of the Act in the upcoming post-compulsory education and training Bill, the effectiveness of the Act in achieving its strategic aims, the role of the remit letter in ensuring national priorities are met, and the regulation of private providers.
		• The Minister also mentioned the intention to create a system of outcome agreements in the new legislation, and the need to balance institutional autonomy with appropriate regulation and accountability for public funding.

- Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, and Huw Morris, director of the skills, higher education and lifelong learning group in Welsh Government, attended a meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee to discuss the post-legislative scrutiny of the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015.
		- The discussion covered topics such as the potential repeal or amendment of the Act by the post-compulsory education and training Bill, the effectiveness of the Act in achieving its strategic aims, the role of the remit letter in ensuring national priorities are met, and the regulation of private providers.
	- The committee also discussed the potential benefits of having national targets to address national priorities and the possibility of introducing more effective policy levers to align the sector with the social, economic, and civic needs of Wales in the new PCET funding body.
	- The committee raised concerns about the Act's focus on individual institutions and its impact on collaboration, as well as the inflexibility of HEFCW's powers of intervention. The Minister acknowledged these concerns and stated that the new commission will be empowered to enable institutions to contribute to national goals and outcomes as part of a civic mission.
	- The committee also discussed the potential benefits and drawbacks of having a single quality assurance body or framework, as well as the regulation of overseas providers. The Minister stated that any quality framework covering higher education will be compatible with ENQA and current UK-wide baseline standards.
	- The committee resolved to meet in private for the remainder of the meeting and for item 1 on 2 October.

• Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, and Huw Morris, director of the skills, higher education and lifelong learning group in Welsh Government, attended a meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee to discuss the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2

• Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, and Huw Morris, director of the skills, higher education and lifelong learning group in Welsh Government, attended a meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee to discuss the post-legislative scrutiny of the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015.
		• The Minister stated that the 2015 Act will be superceded by the new PCETR Bill and that there are experiences from the implementation of the 2015 Act that they want to reflect on as they take forward the new Bill.
	• Sian Gwenllian AM asked questions about quality assurance.
		• The Minister stated that they are aware of concerns in the sector about the proposal to introduce a single quality assessment body and that they are working through options to ensure what quality assurance will look like in the commission.
		• The Minister also stated that any quality framework covering higher education will be compatible with ENQA and current UK-wide baseline standards.

• Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, and Huw Morris, director of the skills, higher education and lifelong learning group in Welsh Government, attended a meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee to discuss the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2

• Discussion of the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015 during a post-legislative scrutiny session
 • Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, and Huw Morris, director of the skills, higher education and lifelong learning group in Welsh Government, attended the meeting
 • Topics discussed include the potential repeal or amendment of the Act by the post-compulsory education and training Bill, the effectiveness of the Act in achieving its objectives, and the regulation of private providers

   • The Act has been framed around institutional autonomy, which has made it difficult for institutions to fulfill national outcomes
   • The new Bill will look to strengthen or add to the current legislation to better achieve the four strategic aims of the Act
   • The current legislation does not allow for the regulation of alternative private providers, and the new Bill may continue with the requirement of being a charity for institutions to be regulated
   • There is no urgent reason to designate part-time or postgraduate courses for the purposes of a fee limit in the new legislation
   • The Act has shifted the parameters of influence that HEFCW or any new tertiary commission could have due to the change in financial circumstances, but the remit letter is still an important mechanism for ensuring national priorities are clearly articulated and acted upon

• Kirsty Williams, Cabinet Secretary for Education, and Eluned Morgan AM, Minister for Welsh Language and Lifelong Learning, discussed the impact of Brexit on higher and further education in Wales
• They were joined by Huw Morris, group director at SHELL, and Marie Knox, deputy director overseeing European transition
• The committee discussed the preparedness of higher education institutions for Brexit, with Huw Morris mentioning ongoing research and visits to individual institutions
• There are no formal risk assessments available for scrutiny, but the Higher Education Funding Council for Wales has been doing specific work and officers have been visiting each institution to ensure they have their own plans in place
• The committee also discussed the impact of Brexit on further education, with Eluned Morgan AM mentioning that the number of EU students in further education colleges is significantly lower and that the number of staff from the EU is about 71
• The committee asked about European social fund funding and was told that about PS15 million a year goes into the further education sector just in relation to apprenticeships
• The committee was also informed about the European transition team, which provides the governance structure for the Welsh Government as a whole in relation to European transition
• The committee discussed the student voice in the discussion and engagement with the student union, with Kirsty Williams AM mentioning a consensus between the Welsh Government, what the universities are asking for, and what the students are asking for, including the importance of participation in the Erasmus programme and the security and stability for EU staff.

• Meeting agenda and attendees
	• Kirsty Williams, Cabinet Secretary for Education, and Eluned Morgan AM, Minister for Welsh Language and Lifelong Learning, along with their officials, attended the meeting to discuss the impact of Brexit on higher and further education.
	
	• Preparedness and risk assessments
	• Nine sector analyses have been conducted, including one for higher education. However, recent work by Cardiff University may have superseded these analyses.
	• No formal risk assessments are available for scrutiny, but the Government has been working with individual institutions to ensure they have their own plans in place.
	
	• Student voice and engagement
	• The National Union of Students has been engaged in discussions with the Government and the sector regarding the importance of Erasmus+ arrangements and the security of funding for European students.
	• The student voice has also expressed concerns about the impact of Brexit on the quality of faculty and the diversity of the student population.
	
	• Specific plans for a 'no deal' Brexit
	• In the event of a 'no deal' Brexit, the HE sector would continue to receive funding for European regional development fund and European social fund programmes until 2020.
	• The Welsh Government has been working with Universities Wales to access resources under the European transition fund to boost international marketing of the HE sector.
	
	• Questions and concerns
	• Members expressed concerns about the impact of Brexit on student recruitment, the balance of profile in the HE sector, and the potential for different immigration rules for international and EU students.
	• The Cabinet Secretary emphasized the importance of working with the sector to ensure their preparedness and to maintain the sustainability of the sector.

• Evaluation of the project process
  • Creativity: team felt they had the opportunity to express themselves, but the flow of information was sometimes disjointed
  • New ideas found: kinetic powered remote control and voice recognition feature
  • Leadership and teamwork: went reasonably well, with separate ideas discussed and combined
  • Means: whiteboard and digital pens were useful, but the computer could be difficult to use at times
  • Costs within budget: no, the project exceeded the budget
  • Project evaluation: the project was evaluated, but it did not fit in with the rest of the company's high-tech products
  • Final questionnaire and meeting summary: to be completed
  • Celebration: to be had
  • Additional notes: the project manager had difficulty getting the computer to work as well as desired, and the team felt the budget was arbitrary and did not allow for more innovative ideas.

- Data collection procedure
	+ Subjects will fill out a speaker information form
	+ Subjects will read a task with German words and isolated proper names
	+ Subjects will choose from a list of tasks and use a map to take notes
	+ Subjects will interact with a computer system that understands their commands
	+ After three tasks, the system will break down and a human operator will take over
- Data collection goals
	+ Understand how people phrase different intentions
	+ Observe how people speak to a machine versus a human operator

• The focus of the meeting was to work on the semantics of the belief-net, which will be the main inference engine for the system's decision-making process.
• The belief-net will make decisions that will turn out to be parameter choices for calls on other modules, such as the natural language understanding thing.
• The group needs to figure out what all the choices are, what influences its choices, and do some technical work on the actual belief relations and probabilities.
• The group also discussed the data collection process and how they will get subjects to record dialogues based on what Fey provokes them to say.
• Robert presented a table of the kinds of things that might come up and the kinds of decisions, with decision nodes and discrete values.
• The group also discussed the idea of limiting the detail of the ontology or types of places that someone could go, and who it would affect in the system.
• The group plans to have Fey collect data from thirty subjects and start next week with the technical work on the belief relations and probabilities.
• The group also discussed the idea of having a prototype that only handles a few of the decision nodes, and that the speech people would benefit from repeated pronunciations of the same thing.

• Discussion on the use of Pupil Deprivation Grant (PDG) in Wales
	• PDG is used to support children who are eligible for free school meals and drive potential, including more able and talented children
	• There is a need for greater awareness and consistency in the use of PDG at the coalface
	• New PDG regional advisers have been appointed to spread good practice and ensure consistent usage of PDG
	• Flexibility in the use of PDG is being considered, such as the 'Ever 2' concept, but an Ever 6 concept would require an additional £40 million
	• Eligibility for free school meals is currently the best measure for identifying pupils to target, but discussions are ongoing with local government to identify different ways
	• The once-a-year eligibility for free school meals is being reviewed for greater flexibility, but implementing an Ever 6 concept would require additional resources
	• The majority of schools are making well thought out and appropriate decisions on how to use PDG, but there is room for improvement
	• The use of PDG is evolving over time, with more schools understanding how to deploy the money for best effect
	• PDG is being used to support good practice in schools, such as tracking of children and evidence-based interventions
	• The intrinsic link between leadership and the use of PDG is recognized, with leadership being a key priority for the Welsh education system
	• The use of PDG is being monitored and challenged by regional challenge advisers, with a focus on targeting, programmes, and impact
	• The new PDG regional advisers are expected to enable more consistent practice across the regions
	• The impact of PDG on attendance and engagement with education for children who have free school meals is being considered
	• PDG can be used to support initiatives such as walking buses and breakfast clubs to improve attendance
	• The link between attendance and attainment is recognized, with a need to improve attendance for free-school-meal children to close the attainment gap
	• PDG can also be used to reduce the higher rates of exclusion for children entitled to free school meals

* Kirsty Williams AM, Cabinet Secretary for Education, Steve Davies, director of the education directorate, and Ruth Conway, deputy director, support for learners division, are questioned about the use of the Pupil Development Grant (PDG) in Wales.
    * The PDG is a significant level of investment (over PS90 million) aimed at supporting children who are eligible for free school meals or more able and talented.
    * The guidance for the use of PDG is considered sufficient, but there is a need for better consistency of practice across regions, which will be enabled by new regional advisers.
    * Eligibility for free school meals is used as a proxy for need, but there are discussions about whether there are different ways to identify relative need, especially with the roll-out of universal credit.
    * The once-a-year eligibility for free school meals can make longer term planning difficult for schools, and there is consideration of greater flexibility in this area.
    * Estyn recognizes that the PDG is being used to push more able and talented children, but there is a need to ensure that this is strategic and happening across all schools.
    * The majority of schools are making well thought out and appropriate decisions on how to use the PDG, but there is room for improvement, especially in leadership within individual schools.
    * The use of PDG is evolving over time, with more schools understanding how best to deploy the money for best effect for students.

• Dr. Frank Atherton, the Chief Medical Officer for Wales, and Nathan Cook, head of the healthy and active branch at Welsh Government, were invited to the Children, Young People and Education Committee to discuss the draft strategy 'Healthy Weight: Healthy Wales'.

• Dr. Atherton expressed confidence that the strategy will deliver for children and young people, as it has a focus on the next generation to prevent the current high prevalence of overweight and obesity from continuing.

• The strategy is informed by engagement with children and young people, including discussions in various fora and visits to schools. A toolkit has also been produced to encourage schools and youth groups to contribute to the consultation.

• Dr. Atherton advised the Minister for health not to adopt the target to halve the prevalence of obesity in children, but to choose a target that balances deliverability with challenge. He also emphasized the importance of performance management and evaluation in the strategy.

• Sian Gwenllian AM asked about the level of investment needed to implement the plan, and Dr. Atherton mentioned that while there is currently investment in child health programs, the final strategy may require new investment. Nathan Cook added that there is currently investment in obesity-related services in health boards, and the strategy aims to drive greater scale and better evaluation of these programs.

• Dr. Atherton advised against hypothecation of the revenue from the levy on sugary soft drinks, and instead suggested thinking about the totality of resource that goes into public health programs and how it can be diverted towards prevention initiatives.

• Lynne Neagle AM asked about the use of the revenue from the levy in other UK nations, and Dr. Atherton mentioned that while there is investment in various initiatives, he is more interested in the totality of resource that goes into prevention initiatives.

• Sian Gwenllian AM asked about partnership working and how to avoid a situation where everyone is responsible but no one is accountable. Dr. Atherton mentioned that a national implementation board will be established to oversee the delivery of the plan, and it will be accountable to Ministers.

• Janet Finch-Saunders AM asked which Minister the board should be accountable to, and Dr. Atherton suggested that health should lead the strategy but it needs broad ownership across government.

- Dr. Frank Atherton, the Chief Medical Officer for Wales, and Nathan Cook, head of the healthy and active branch at Welsh Government, were invited to discuss the draft strategy 'Healthy Weight: Healthy Wales'.
		+ They were asked about their confidence in the strategy delivering for children and young people, to which they responded that they were very confident and that the strategy has to focus on the next generation to prevent the current high prevalence of overweight and obesity from continuing.
	- Dr. Atherton and Nathan Cook were asked about the engagement they had with children and young people to inform the draft strategy.
		+ They mentioned discussing with young people in various fora, visiting schools, and having a young person attend the joint launch of the consultation. They also mentioned producing a toolkit for schools to get involved in the consultation.
	- Sian Gwenllian AM asked about leadership and the possibility of a target for reducing obesity among children.
		+ Dr. Atherton advised that they may consider a target in the final strategy, but that the target of halving the prevalence of obesity in children adopted in England and Scotland is more aspirational than deliverable.
	- Sian Gwenllian AM also asked about the level of investment needed to implement the plan.
		+ Dr. Atherton mentioned that resourcing will be important and that they are currently making investments in child health programs, but that they need to look at existing programs and see if they can be made more effective or if new investment is needed.
	- Lynne Neagle AM asked about the investment from the sugar levy and if it is being used effectively.
		+ Dr. Atherton mentioned that the revenue from the sugar levy is less than anticipated due to industry reformulation, but that they are using the funding and looking at how to drive greater scale and better evaluate current programs.
	- Sian Gwenllian AM asked about partnership working and how they will create a system that co-ordinates action and drives change across relevant partners.
		+ Dr. Atherton mentioned that they will need some sort of structure to lead this and that leadership will be important, with the First Minister having ultimate responsibility. He also mentioned that they will need to make sure that the public sector and industry are engaged in this.

• The Children, Young People and Education Committee held a meeting to discuss the 'Healthy Weight: Healthy Wales' draft strategy.
	• Dr Frank Atherton, the Chief Medical Officer for Wales, and Nathan Cook, head of the healthy and active branch at Welsh Government, were in attendance.
	• The committee inquired about the strategy's focus on children and young people, engagement with this demographic, leadership, and partnerships.
	• Dr Atherton mentioned that the strategy is an all-age approach, and they have had engagement with children and young people through various forums, including schools and youth ambassadors.
	• Nathan Cook added that they have produced a toolkit to encourage schools and youth groups to contribute to the consultation.
	• Dr Atherton clarified that he advised the Minister for Health not to adopt an overly ambitious target for reducing childhood obesity but did not rule out having a target in the final strategy.
	• The investment needed to implement the plan is still being assessed, and the revenue from the soft drinks levy could potentially be used to support the plan.
	• The committee discussed the importance of data collection, leadership, and partnerships in implementing the plan effectively.
	• The committee also talked about the role of the national implementation board, the use of the planning system to restrict hot food takeaways around schools, and the integration of community sport infrastructure in new schools.

• The last meeting was a recap of the presentation by the Industrial Designer regarding the new remote control.
	• The remote should have a child-friendly design with few buttons, be colorful, and have star-shaped or other shaped buttons. It should also have an oversized design so it's not easily lost.
	• The remote should have nine channel buttons, a next button, volume buttons, subtitle buttons, a switch to control features, color contrast, sharpness, and a memory switch. A mute button and speech recognition are also desired features.
	• The Industrial Designer proposed using a strong plastic material for the case, with an integrated circuit board and a temperature-resistant chip. She also suggested including a timer and/or alarm facility, as well as a rechargeable battery.
	• The marketing expert suggested that the remote should be small, easy to use, and eye-catching. She also emphasized the importance of getting to market before competitors do, and focusing on one or two key features for the marketing campaign.
	• The team decided that the special feature they want to include is a speech recognizer, with the energy source being a battery-operated chip. The design will be trendy, compact, and strong, with buttons.
	• The Industrial Designer presented a model of the remote, which is snail-shaped, blue, and has yellow buttons. The material for the case will be plastic, and the buttons will be made of soft rubber. The light emitting diode will be a fluorescent green bulb like an ordinary infrared.

• Feedback regarding the prototype of the remote:
	+ Look and design: The prototype has a snail shape, is blue in color with yellow buttons, and is compact and attractive. The material used for the case is plastic, and the buttons are made of soft rubber. The LED is a fluorescent green bulb like an ordinary infrared.
	+ Features: The remote includes a switch on/off button, a mute button on both sides, one to nine buttons for controlling programs, two buttons for increasing or decreasing volume, two buttons for scrolling up or down channels, a menu button, and a swapping button for changing channels. It also has an inbuilt voice recogniser.
	+ Marketing considerations: The remote is easy to use with one thumb, has a prominent on-off button, and has symbols on the buttons for international markets.
	+ Additional feature: A holder for the remote in the shape of a snail shell.

<summary>

• Financing: The energy source is battery, and the electronics use a simple chip on print. The case is double curved, made of plastic with special colors, and has push buttons with symbols, special form, and special material (rubber). The total cost is within budget at eight point two euros.

• Production evaluation: The marketing expert suggests showing the prototype to people from various age and socio-economic groups for fine tuning and to avoid any potential issues with the product. The shape, size, color, feel, and functionality of the prototype are all given high ratings.

• Adding voice recognition: There is no room for the voice recogniser in the current budget, but there is still four euros left to spend. The team decides to settle for whatever quality they can get for that price, even if it may not be the greatest quality.

• Evaluation scale: The team evaluates the shape, size, color, feel, and functionality of the prototype, giving each a rating of one (good) or higher. There is room for creativity and more features, such as adding more buttons or consolidating usage. The team is happy with the project process, leadership, team work, and means used. The costs are within budget, and the project has been evaluated.

</summary>

- Discussion of issues with the PDA microphones:
  • The PDA microphones are often far from the speakers, which can cause issues with room noise and reverberation.
  • There is a pre-emphasis filter in the STRUT implementation, which may affect the high-pass filtering of the microphone input.
  • It is important to check the filtering for any microphone used with the PDA.
- Discussion of spectral subtraction and variance normalization:
  • Spectral subtraction can help reduce background noise, but it can also increase the variance of the signal.
  • Variance normalization can help adjust for differences in energy between different channels, but it can also make the speech and noise portions of the signal more similar.
  • It is important to find the right balance between spectral subtraction and variance normalization to improve voice activity detection and speech recognition.
- Discussion of the next meeting and ongoing work:
  • The next meeting is in June.
  • There are ongoing efforts to reduce latency and incorporate a second stream of data.
  • It is important to continue working on these and other issues to improve the overall performance of the system.

		• Concerns about rubber casing protecting delicate technology and interchangeable plates

		• Command interface: requires typing textual commands and input at keyboard
		• Command interface more useful for remote control, simplistic design

* Dr. David Blaney, Chief Executive of the Higher Education Funding Council for Wales, and Bethan Owen, Director of Institutional Engagement, were invited to give evidence on the impact of Brexit on higher and further education in Wales.
    - They were asked about the evidence they have seen so far of Brexit's impact on Welsh higher education.
    - Dr. Blaney mentioned that uncertainty about relationships and arrangements with Europe is one of the most significant issues confronting university management at the moment.
    - He also mentioned that they are beginning to see some impact in terms of applications from EU students and anecdotally, some signs that there are increasing difficulties in the UK sector in playing in some of the EU collaborative research activities.
    - Dr. Blaney also mentioned that the financial impact of Brexit is hard to be clear about, but they are beginning to see some impact in terms of applications from EU students.
    - Bethan Owen mentioned that the European Union-domiciled applicants to Wales have decreased by 8 per cent, which contrasts with a 2 per cent increase for English institutions.
    - She also mentioned that non-EU students have also decreased by 9 per cent to Welsh institutions, again contrasting with a 7 per cent increase in England.

  * John Griffiths AM asked about the main pressures on the Welsh higher education sector at the moment.
    - Bethan Owen mentioned that the funding position is the main pressure.
    - She also mentioned that the recommendations made by Sir Ian Diamond in his review of higher education funding and student finance are in the process of being implemented.
    - She also mentioned that the challenges introduced by Brexit are in addition to those that the Diamond report was addressing.
    - She also mentioned that the other pressures relate to student recruitment, pay and pension costs, increased student expectations for modern facilities and infrastructure, and uncertainty about potential consequences that could arise from the review in England of fees and funding.

  * Llyr Gruffydd AM asked about European Union students and enrolment.
    - Bethan Owen mentioned that it is very difficult to forecast if Wales is going to do less well than England in terms of European Union students and enrolment.
    - She also mentioned that the arrangements that have changed from 2018-19 also impact on EU students

* The Higher Education Funding Council for Wales (HEFCW) is giving evidence to the Children, Young People and Education Committee regarding the impact of Brexit on higher and further education in Wales.
    - Dr David Blaney, Chief Executive of HEFCW, and Bethan Owen, Director of Institutional Engagement, are in attendance.
  * The Chair of the Committee notes that there have been apologies from Hefin David and Lynne Neagle.
  * Julie Morgan AM begins the questioning by asking about the evidence HEFCW has seen of Brexit's impact on Welsh higher education so far.
    - Dr Blaney responds by stating that HEFCW is apolitical and will stick to the facts, but notes that the impact of Brexit is a matter of politics.
    - He identifies areas of uncertainty, including the relationships and arrangements with Europe, and the exposure of the HE sector in Wales to EU-sourced funding.
  * Bethan Owen provides details on the decrease in EU and international student applications to Welsh institutions.
    - There has been an 8% decrease in EU-domiciled applicants and a 9% decrease in non-EU international students.
  * John Griffiths AM asks about the main pressures on the Welsh higher education sector at the moment.
    - Bethan Owen identifies the funding position, student recruitment, pay and pension costs, infrastructure and capital expenditure, and the uncertainty around potential consequences of the review of fees and funding in England.
  * Llyr Gruffydd AM asks about the factors leading to the decrease in EU student applications.
    - Dr Blaney suggests that the change in student support arrangements and the relative levels of investment in facilities may be contributing factors.
  * Mark Reckless AM questions the explanation for the decrease in non-EU student applications.
    - Dr Blaney and Bethan Owen suggest that this may be due to a mix effect and perceptions of how welcome overseas and international students are in the UK.
  * Darren Millar AM asks about the extent to which HEFCW has been able to plan for the potential impacts of Brexit.
    - Bethan Owen explains that they receive funding annually and use financial forecasts from institutions to monitor sustainability.
  * The discussion then turns to the impact of Brexit on fee and access plans

• Potential difficulties for researcher collaborations and networks after Brexit
		• Discussion of the impact of Brexit on Welsh higher education
			- Uncertainty about relationships and arrangements with Europe affecting sustainability of higher education providers
			- Exposure of the HE sector in Wales to EU-sourced funding, including EU students, structural funds, and EU research funding
			- Decrease in applications from EU students and potential difficulties in collaborative research activities
		• Financial and economic impact of Brexit on Welsh higher education
			- Financial impact of Brexit on the UK economy affecting tax revenue and HE sector funding
			- Turbulence expected for institutions, with uncertainty about the specifics
			- Institutions need to be sighted on Brexit-related challenges and prepare for them
		• Recruitment and funding pressures on the Welsh higher education sector
			- Decrease in EU and international student applications, with potential reasons including changes in student support arrangements and relative levels of investment in facilities
			- Main pressures on the sector include the funding position, student recruitment, pay and pension costs, capital expenditure and borrowing, and potential consequences of the Augar review in England
			- Brexit challenges are in addition to those addressed by the Diamond report's recommendations
		• Uncertainty about potential consequences of Brexit for EU students and enrolment
			- It is unclear whether Wales will do less well than England in recruiting EU students, but potential reasons include changes in student support arrangements and perceptions of how welcome overseas and international students are
			- The sector is working on improving perceptions and attractiveness to international students
			- The final enrolment numbers will provide more clarity on the impact of Brexit on EU student recruitment.

- The Welsh baccalaureate qualification is valued by the Cabinet Secretary for Education in Wales, who believes it helps ensure a broad and balanced curriculum for young people.
		+ The Cabinet Secretary values the qualification for its ability to develop knowledge and skills in core subjects, as well as preparing students for further study and the world of work.
	- The Welsh baccalaureate has been positively received by many learners and teachers, but there have been concerns raised about workload, balancing the qualification with other subjects, and the impact on well-being.
		+ The Cabinet Secretary acknowledges these concerns and believes that there is room for improvement in the qualification.
	- The Welsh baccalaureate is valued more by some learners than others, with some students reporting positive experiences and others expressing concerns about its impact on their well-being and ability to take additional A-levels.
		+ The Cabinet Secretary believes that leadership in schools can have a significant impact on how the baccalaureate is received by learners.
	- The Cabinet Secretary intends to ensure consistent support and enthusiasm for the baccalaureate from school leaders, and is working with Qualifications Wales and the WJEC to develop a joint communication plan.
		+ The Cabinet Secretary also plans to address concerns about the variability in the way the qualification is delivered in different schools.
	- The Cabinet Secretary is aware of concerns about the inconsistency in the way universities value the Welsh baccalaureate, and is working to improve communication with employers and universities to ensure they understand the value of the qualification.
		+ The Cabinet Secretary is also working to ensure that the qualification is consistently delivered in schools, and is considering issuing guidance to schools on how to deliver the qualification effectively.

• The Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill aims to prohibit all forms of physical punishment to protect children's rights and ensure equal protection from physical punishment as adults.

	+ 70% of individuals who responded to the written consultation do not support the Bill.
	+ Parents who oppose the Bill argue that they understand the difference between child abuse and a light smack from a loving parent.

• Deputy Minister Julie Morgan AM believes that the Bill is necessary to update the law and make it clearer for parents and people working with children.

	+ Morgan argues that there should not be an excuse for physical punishment of children in the law.
	+ She also believes that defining acceptable ways of hitting or punishing children sends a confused message.

• The Bill does not create a new offence, but rather removes a defence to an offence of common assault.

	+ Ireland introduced similar legislation through an amendment to a Bill without detailed preparation and has not experienced significant negative impacts or increased workload.
	+ Wales has an implementation group to address issues and set up four work streams to look at parenting advice and support, data collection, evaluation and monitoring, operations, procedures and processes, and out-of-court disposals and diversions.

• The Bill's explanatory memorandum states that there is no definitive evidence that reasonable physical punishment causes negative outcomes for children.

	+ However, the Wales Centre for Public Policy's report found that all physical punishment, under all conditions, is potentially harmful to children.
	+ There is no peer-reviewed research that says physically punishing a child will improve things or have favorable outcomes.

• The Bill's implementation group includes representatives from the police, police and crime commissioners, the Crown Prosecution Service, the Association of Directors of Social Services Cymru, the Association of Directors of Education in Wales, the Welsh Local Government Association, the legal profession, and the third sector.

	+ These organizations are committed to making the legislation work and have set up four work streams to look at various issues.
	+ The group will also be updated on the progress of the awareness strategy that the Welsh Government will be bringing in.

• The Bill will not overwhelm public services, as shown by evidence from other countries.

• Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, Steve Davies, director of the education directorate, and Huw Morris, group director, skills, higher education and lifelong learning, attended a virtual meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee to discuss the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales.
	• The Minister expressed her gratitude to everyone who has been working hard to keep schools open for vulnerable children and the children of key workers, and thanked parents and carers for their efforts in home schooling.
	• The Minister outlined five principles that will guide her decision on when and how to reopen schools, including considering the safety and well-being of children, young people and staff, building confidence for parents and professionals, and addressing practical issues such as social distancing and school transport.
	• The Minister confirmed that schools will not reopen imminently, and that she has not been given a date by the Chief Medical Officer as to when it might be safe to do so.
	• The Minister also confirmed that the principles apply to further education and higher education, and that the Welsh Government is working closely with representatives of the HE sector to include them in the planning process.
	• The Minister answered questions from Members on a range of topics, including the current situation in schools, the impact on particular groups of children, and the challenges facing higher and further education.

• The Welsh Government discussed the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales during a virtual meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee.

		+ The meeting was held in accordance with Standing Order 34.19, which allowed for the public to be excluded to protect public health.
		+ The meeting was broadcast live on Senedd.tv, with all participants joining via video conference.
		+ A record of the proceedings was published as usual.
		+ The meeting was bilingual, with simultaneous translation from Welsh to English available.

		+ The Minister emphasized the importance of protecting the health and well-being of children, young people, and staff in education settings.
		+ The Minister also thanked parents and carers for their efforts in keeping their children at home to reduce pressure on the education system and the NHS.
	• Hefin David AM asked the first question, inquiring about the Minister's five principles for reopening schools.
		+ The Minister stated that schools will move to a new phase when it is safe to do so, based on advice from the chief medical officer and the chief scientific officer.
		+ The Minister also emphasized the importance of clear communication and planning for parents and staff, as well as considering the practical challenges of reopening schools.
		+ The Minister made it clear that a return to normal is not imminent.
	• Sian Gwenllian AM asked about the importance of testing in reopening schools.
		+ The Minister stated that testing, tracing, and quarantine will be crucial in the next phase of the Government's response to the pandemic.
		+ The Minister also emphasized the importance of working on a four-nation basis and looking at best international evidence.
		+ The Minister made it clear that there has not been a date given for reopening schools.

* Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, Steve Davies, director of the education directorate, and Huw Morris, group director, skills, higher education and lifelong learning, attend a virtual meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee to discuss the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales.
    + The meeting is being conducted remotely and is being broadcast live on Senedd.tv.
    + The Minister makes an opening statement, expressing gratitude to those keeping school hubs open and providing remote learning.
    + Hefin David AM asks about the reopening of schools, to which the Minister responds that it will be based on advice from the chief medical officer and chief scientific officer, and will not be imminent.
    + The Minister outlines the principles that will guide her decision-making, including the safety and well-being of children, young people, and staff, clear communication, and consideration of which groups of children should return first.
    + Sian Gwenllian AM asks about the importance of testing in reopening schools, and the Minister emphasizes the need to follow medical and scientific advice.
    + Suzy Davies AM asks about school absences and the potential relaxation of truancy rules, and the Minister states that she will seek to reduce burdens on schools and that attendance will be an important factor.
    + The Minister provides data on the number of schools open and the number of children and staff attending, with the majority being children of key workers.

- Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, discussed the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales during a virtual meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee.
  * She expressed gratitude to school staff, key workers, and parents for their efforts in keeping schools open and supporting children's learning at home.
  * Williams highlighted the challenges faced by the education system and emphasized the importance of protecting the health and well-being of children, young people, and staff.
- The Minister outlined five principles that will guide her decision on when schools might reopen, including considering the safety and well-being of children, young people, and staff, clear communication, identifying appropriate groups for accessing education within a school setting, and ensuring safe operational measures.
  * She mentioned that schools will not be returning to normal imminently and that a phased return, potentially starting with vulnerable children and those with additional learning needs, is more likely.
  * Williams also mentioned that evidence and information will be crucial in building confidence for parents and professionals, and that this evidence will be shared transparently.
- The discussion also covered topics such as the current situation of school hubs, testing for school staff, and the impact on particular groups of children, including vulnerable children and those with additional learning needs.
  * The Minister mentioned that, on average, 1% of children in Wales attend these locations, with 85% being vulnerable children or children of key workers.
  * She also mentioned that 15 teachers have been tested for COVID-19, with 2 testing positive. Testing will be crucial in the next phase of the Government's response to the pandemic.

• Topic of the meeting: Impact of the coronavirus pandemic on education in Wales

• Participants:
  • Lynne Neagle AM, Chair of the Children, Young People and Education Committee
  • Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education
  • Steve Davies, Director of the Education Directorate
  • Huw Morris, Group Director, Skills, Higher Education and Lifelong Learning
  • Rob Orford, Chief Scientific Adviser for Health
  • Other Assembly Members (AMs)

• Key points:
  • The Welsh Government has decided to close all schools from March 23 for statutory education provision due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
  • From next week, schools will have a new purpose, including supporting those most in need and ensuring continuity of learning.
  • The decision to cancel the summer exam series was announced, with learners due to sit these exams being awarded a fair grade to recognize their work.
  • The Welsh Government is working with local government and schools to develop and finalize plans to support vulnerable children and ensure continuity of learning.
  • Schools are expected to provide safe and secure places for children of those on the front-line response to the coronavirus outbreak.

• Additional information:
  • The Welsh Government has a dedicated website page with all relevant information about coronavirus.
  • A frequently asked education questions page is being developed to update and respond to questions from the public.
  • Schools are already taking the initiative and having conversations with parents about what their needs will be.
  • The Welsh Government is working with local authorities and the Council for Wales of Voluntary Youth Services to deploy youth workers and other staff to support the provision for children.

• Future actions:
  • The Welsh Government will continue to build resilience and adapt to changing public health advice.
  • Schools will receive letters today about the expectations for schools next week.
  • Qualifications Wales and the WJEC will operationalize the decision on exam cancellations and communicate with schools as quickly as possible.
  • The Welsh Government will ensure that EMA continues to be paid to all students who are entitled.
  • Conversations are ongoing with universities and the Student Loans Company to ensure that student maintenance payments continue as normal.

• The Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill is being discussed in a scrutiny session of the Children, Young People and Education Committee.
	• Witnesses include Sally Jenkins, chair of All Wales Heads of Children's Services, Alastair Birch, senior system leader for equalities and safeguarding at Pembrokeshire County Council, and Councillor Huw David, Welsh Local Government Association spokesperson for health and social care and leader of Bridgend County Borough Council.
	• The witnesses are asked about their general support for the Bill and why they think the current law is ineffective or unclear.
	• They explain that the current legislation allows for physical punishment, which goes against the rights of the child as outlined in the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child.
	• They also discuss the potential unintended consequences of the Bill, including the need for greater clarity around the definition of what constitutes corporal punishment and the importance of simplicity in the Bill.
	• The witnesses emphasize the need for awareness raising and training for professionals in education settings to support the implementation of the Bill.
	• They also mention the importance of making it clear to parents, guardians, and the public that the legislation is not trying to criminalize parents.
	• The discussion touches on the issue of resources and who would be responsible for paying for awareness raising and training.

• The Welsh Government has asked the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) to review the progress of Welsh education against the national mission.
	• The OECD review is part of the Welsh Government's ongoing development of self-evaluation, aiming to avoid accepting their own orthodoxy and to have external verification of where they are.
	• The OECD was able to talk to whoever they felt it was important to talk to, including practitioners on the ground, elements of the middle tier, and Welsh Government.
	• The reports of this committee have also formed parts of the OECD's review, looking at how the Senedd itself has contributed to and has held the Government to account.
	• The OECD's report is expected to be published on 23 March, and the Minister intends to make a statement to the Chamber on 24 March.
	• The School Standards and Organisation (Wales) Act 2013 gives local authorities extensive powers of intervention in schools if they feel that is necessary.
	• The types of interventions that have been used include appointing additional governors to governing bodies, suspending a school's delegated budget, or applying to the Welsh Government to entirely replace a governing body and establish an intervention board.
	• The Welsh Government has not used those powers to date, but encourages local authorities to take a proactive approach to intervention and to use those powers.
	• The national evaluation and improvement resource is being developed to give continuity of approach right the way across Wales and to develop the skills within the system to have robust self-evaluation.
	• The resource is being tested and evaluated, with the intention of introducing it across the system at the start of the new academic year, in September 2020.
